title: Week Sixteen and Seventeen in Trade
content: Week Seventeen - CIT Unequivocally Strikes Down IEEPA Tariffs as Invalid - On May 28, 2025, a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court ...
resumen:
**Week Seventeen**

*   On May 28, 2025, a three-judge panel of the U.S. Court of International Trade (CIT) held tariffs imposed by the Trump Administration pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act of 1977 (IEEPA) to be unlawful and invalid.
*   The CIT‚Äôs order covers IEEPA tariffs imposed against Canada, Mexico and China related to fentanyl trade (IEEPA Fentanyl tariffs) as well as IEEPA reciprocal tariffs of 10% imposed on imports from all trading partners (IEEPA Reciprocal tariffs).
*   The Court vacated the Executive Orders imposing the various IEEPA tariffs, including all modifications and amendments thereto and permanently enjoined their operation.
*   The CIT ordered the administration to issue necessary administrative orders within 10 calendar days to effectuate the permanent injunction.
*   The government has filed a motion to stay the CIT‚Äôs order pending the appeal which it filed before the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit (CAFC).
*   The court has ordered the plaintiffs to reply to the motion for a stay by June 2, 2025.
*   The government also filed a motion for stay with the CAFC, which has for the moment paused implementation of the CIT‚Äôs order until it considers the government‚Äôs motion.
*   The CAFC has ordered the plaintiffs to respond to the government‚Äôs motion by June 5 with the government having another opportunity to respond by June 9.
*   On May 29, 2025, US District Court for the District of Columbia in Learning Resources, Inc. et al v. Donald J. Trump et al granted a preliminary injunction staying the imposition of the IEEPA tariffs on the grounds that IEEPA does not grant tariff authority.
*   The court also held that CIT did not have jurisdiction over the case because IEEPA is not a ‚Äúlaw of the United States providing for . . . tariffs.‚Äù
*   The case was filed by Plaintiffs Learning Resources, Inc. and hand2mind, Inc.
*   The court issued a preliminary injunction and enjoined the collection of tariffs against the two plaintiffs.
*   It also stayed operation of the preliminary injunction for 14 days.
*   The government has appealed the decision to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit.
*   On May 30, 2025 CBP issued CSMS Message # 65201773 updating its guidance for in-transit goods in CSMS # 64680374, ‚ÄúGUIDANCE ‚Äì Reciprocal Tariffs, April 5 and April 9, 2025, Effective Dates‚Äù.
*   CBP has extended the May 28, 2025 date to June 16, 2025.
*   Articles of countries subject to IEEPA Reciprocal tariffs that were (1) loaded onto a vessel at the port of loading and in-transit on the final mode of transport on or after April 5, 2025, and before April 9, 2025, and (2) are entered for consumption, or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption, before June 16, 2025, are subject to the 10% additional tariff rate.
*   Products of China that are (1) loaded onto a vessel at the port of loading and in transit on the final mode of transport on or after April 9, 2025, and before April 10, 2025, and (2) are entered for consumption, or withdrawn from warehouse for consumption, before June 16, 2025, are subject to the 10% additional tariff rate.
*   On May 23, 2025, the U.S. Treasury Department‚Äôs Office of Foreign Assets Control (‚ÄúOFAC‚Äù) issued Syria General License 25 (‚ÄúGL 25‚Äù) in order to authorize certain transactions which would otherwise be prohibited under existing OFAC Syrian sanctions.
*   GL 25 generally authorizes U.S. persons to perform transactions with Syria provided that those transactions do not involve blocked persons listed on OFAC‚Äôs Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List (‚ÄúSDN List‚Äù).
*   GL 25 authorizes U.S. persons to transact with the President Ahmed al-Sharaa regime of the Government of Syria as in existence on or after May 13, 2025.
*   GL 25 also authorizes U.S. persons to transact with specific SDNs listed on its attached Annex A as well as entities in which those SDNs directly or indirectly hold a 50 percent or greater ownership interest.
*   The SDNs listed on GL 25‚Äôs Annex A include (but are not limited to) the Commercial Bank of Syria, the Central Bank of Syria, the Syrian Petroleum Company and the Syrian Ministry of Petroleum and Mineral Resources.
*   OFAC issued a FAQ Fact Sheet on May 28, 2025 to provide additional guidance on GL 25.
*   The separate U.S. Export Administration Regulations (‚ÄúEAR‚Äù) continue to impose a nearly complete prohibition on exports and reexports of all items ‚Äúsubject to the EAR‚Äù to Syria (subject to a narrow exception for food and medicine classified as EAR99).
*   The U.S. Commerce Department‚Äôs Bureau of Industry and Security (‚ÄúBIS‚Äù) has not yet taken any action to lift the EAR‚Äôs Syria embargo or issue any sort of License Exception equivalent to OFAC‚Äôs GL 25.

**Week Sixteen**

*   On May 20, 2025, the Department of Commerce issued a Federal Register notice (‚ÄúNotice‚Äù) detailing the process for car manufacturers eligible for preferential tariff treatment under the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) to determine and report the percentage of U.S.-origin content in their vehicles to qualify for reduced Section 232 tariffs.
*   The Notice specifies that once the Department of Commerce completes its review and determines the U.S.-origin content, it will inform both the importer and U.S. Customs and Border Protection of the portion of the vehicle subject to tariffs.
*   The Notice clarifies that the submission process described does not cover subsequent adjustments under the Section 232 action, which allows for customs rebates on certain imported parts used in vehicles assembled in the United States.
*   The Notice states that public comments on this process will not be accepted, as the matter falls under foreign affairs and is therefore exempt from the requirements of the Administrative Procedure Act.
*   On May 22, 2025, the Department of Commerce‚Äôs Bureau of Industry and Security (‚ÄúBIS‚Äù) released a diverse list of 58 requests‚Äîcovering a diverse list of steel and aluminum products ranging from forks and spoons to drones and auto parts‚Äîfor new products proposed as derivatives subject to Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act on steel and aluminum products.

title: China hits back on Trump claims as trade war reignites
content: China hit back Monday on President Donald Trump‚Äôs claims the Asian country was in breach of a new trade agreement, countering that the U.S. itself was undermining the deal with new sanctions.
resumen:
China hit back Monday, July 2, on President Donald Trump‚Äôs claims the Asian country was in breach of a new trade agreement, countering that the U.S. itself was undermining the deal with new sanctions.
The new rift was dragging down U.S. stock indexes Monday morning and threatens to reignite a Sino-U.S. trade war that had cooled somewhat following high-level trade talks that led to a temporary agreement last month.
A statement from China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce released Monday said Trump administration actions ‚Äúseriously undermine the existing consensus reached at the Geneva economic and trade talks, and seriously damage China‚Äôs legitimate rights and interests.‚Äù
Chinese officials also pointed to recent signaling from the U.S. about potential new regulations for advanced microchips and the revocation of U.S. visas for Chinese students, per CBS News, as evidence that the U.S. was acting in bad faith following the trade deal.
A White House official told CNBC that Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are likely to speak this week.
In Truth Social post last Friday, Trump said that the deal had led to greater economic stability for China and ‚Äúeverybody was happy‚Äù but alluded to China violating terms of the agreement.
Trump wrote: ‚ÄúThe bad news is that China, perhaps not surprisingly to some, HAS TOTALLY VIOLATED ITS AGREEMENT WITH US. So much for being Mr. NICE GUY!‚Äù
Trump‚Äôs social media post last Friday morning offered no details about the nature of China‚Äôs alleged breach, later reporting indicated the president‚Äôs issue was focused on China‚Äôs export rules on rare earth minerals.
China controls 90% of the world‚Äôs rare earth elements production capacity and, according to the U.S. Department of Energy, the minerals play a critical role in U.S. national security, energy independence and economic growth.
In a deal announced May 12, both countries agreed to roll back reciprocal tariffs to a 10% rate for a 90-day period beginning May 14.
Other, sector-specific U.S. trade levies on steel, aluminum and automobiles remained in place, as did a 20% tariff Trump announced earlier this year to address fentanyl trafficking.
The announcement followed two days of meetings in Geneva between Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent and U.S. Trade Representative Jamieson Greer with a delegation of Chinese officials.
Trump, at the time, lauded the deal as ‚Äúhistoric.‚Äù
Trade traffic between the countries was upended in April when a series of retaliatory tariffs drove levies to 145% on Chinese imports and 125% on U.S. exports to China.
At a rally in Pennsylvania last Friday, Trump announced plans to raise a sector-specific tariff on steel imports from 25% to 50%.
In a ruling issued last Wednesday, the U.S. Court of International Trade struck down a wide swath of trade tariff decrees made by Trump since he took office.
A day later, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted a temporary hold on the lower court ruling.
The plaintiffs in the lower court case have until June 5 to respond to the stay decision and Trump‚Äôs legal team will have until June 9 to develop its argument for the pause to remain in place as the appeals process plays out.
The trade court ruling, should it stand, impacts new tariffs Trump has issued, without congressional approval, under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act.

title: What‚Äôs good for politicians is good for General Motors
content: General Motors CEO Mary Barra earned $29.5 million last year, and it‚Äôs hard to argue that she isn‚Äôt earning her keep. The automaker sold more cars in the U.S. than any other company last year, and its ...
resumen: General Motors CEO Mary Barra's policy views and business strategies change with the man in the White House. Mary Barra earned $29.5 million last year. The automaker sold more cars in the U.S. than any other company last year, and its profits have doubled in her 11 years as CEO. She pleases politicians. While doubling down on manufacturing profitable gas guzzlers, Ms. Barra promoted electric vehicles to ingratiate herself to Democrats. She praised President Trump‚Äôs auto tariffs, which the company estimates will dent its profits by $5 billion this year. In 2018 Ms. Barra announced a corporate restructuring that involved closing four U.S. plants. In 2019, GM announced plans to create 450 new factory jobs in Ohio, as well as a joint venture with LG Chem to build a $2.3 billion EV battery plant near the closed Lordstown factory. Mr. Trump repaid the favor with the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement. After Mr. Trump lost re-election, Ms. Barra began kowtowing to her new master in Washington. GM rapidly did a U-turn on California‚Äôs EV rules. On Jan. 28, 2021, GM announced plans to go all-electric by 2035. Ms. Barra cheered Mr. Biden‚Äôs plans to rev up fuel-economy standards at a White House event. Ms. Barra lent her support to the Democrats‚Äô $5 trillion Build Back Better legislation. The bill included a $12,500 tax credit for EVs built with union labor. The Inflation Reduction Act included rich subsidies for EVs and battery production. The Biden Energy Department awarded GM a $2.5 billion low-interest loan for its battery joint venture with LG. GM this spring lobbied Congress to reverse the federal waiver for California‚Äôs EV mandate. Last week, GM scrapped a plan to make EV motors at an upstate New York factory. Instead, the company will make high-tech V-8 engines for full-size trucks and SUVs.

title: Trump Tariff Tracker -- May 21
content: In the last week, the winds of change have calmed a bit on what has been a tumultuous sea of tariffs over the last four months. The ...
resumen:
In the last week, the winds of change have calmed a bit on what has been a tumultuous sea of tariffs over the last four months. The Trump Administration has announced no new tariff measures, and no new investigations of imports have been launched by the USTR or Commerce Department. President Trump said on Friday, May 16, that the U.S. would not be able to negotiate deals for lower tariffs with each of the countries that were subject to country-specific tariff rates before the 90-day pause on the reciprocal tariffs expires on July 8. The Secretaries of Commerce and Treasury will be directly informing U.S. trading partners of their new country-specific tariff rates. The comment period for the Commerce Department‚Äôs Section 232 Investigation on imports of commercial aircraft and jet engines, and parts for commercial aircraft and jet engines remains open until June 3, 2025.

Here is the developing landscape of U.S. tariffs as of May 21, 2025:

*   **Global:** Reciprocal tariffs ‚Äì 10% ad valorem duty. China-specific 54% ad valorem duty on de minimis valued imports, other country-specific duties suspended. Certain goods excluded. Revised 5/12/2025. Implemented 4/2/2025.
*   **China:** Chinese Vessels ‚Äì Port Entry Fees on Chinese owned or built vessels, and foreign-built car carriers. Implemented: 4/17/2025.
*   **Global:** Automobiles ‚Äì 25% ad valorem duty on imports of automobiles (with certain allowances for USMCA-qualifying autos) and certain automobile parts (with limited tariff offsets). Implemented 4/3/2025 (effective 5/3/2025 for automobile parts).
*   **Global:** All goods imported from any country that imports Venezuelan oil ‚Äì discretionary 25% ad valorem duty may be imposed. Implemented 4/2/2025.
*   **Global:** Steel ‚Äì 25% ad valorem duty on imports of steel articles and derivative products with no exemptions or exclusions. Implemented: 3/12/2025.
*   **Global:** Aluminum ‚Äì 25% ad valorem duty on imports of aluminum articles and derivative products with no exemptions or exclusions. Implemented: 3/12/2025.
*   **Canada:** 10% ad valorem duty on non-USMCA-qualifying energy and potash. 25% ad valorem duty on all other non-USMCA-qualifying products of Canada. Implemented: 3/4/2025; 4/2/2025 (updated).
*   **Mexico:** 25% ad valorem duty on all non-USMCA-qualifying products of Mexico. Implemented: 3/4/2025; 4/2/2025 (updated).
*   **China:** 20% ad valorem duty on all products of China. Implemented: 3/4/2025.
*   **Global:** Aircraft and Engines ‚Äì potential tariffs on imports of commercial aircraft and jet engines, and aircraft/engine parts. Pending: Section 232 Investigation.
*   **Global:** Critical Minerals ‚Äì potential tariffs on imports of processed critical minerals and derivative products. Pending: Section 232 Investigation.
*   **Global:** Medium & Heavy Duty Trucks ‚Äì potential tariffs on imports of medium-duty trucks, heavy-duty trucks, and medium- and heavy-duty truck parts. Pending: Section 232 Investigation.
*   **Global:** Semiconductors ‚Äì potential tariffs on imports of semiconductors, SME, and derivative products. Pending: Section 232 Investigation.
*   **Global:** Pharmaceuticals‚Äì potential tariffs on imports of pharmaceuticals, pharmaceutical ingredients, and derivative products. Pending: Section 232 Investigation.
*   **Global:** Copper ‚Äì potential tariffs on imports of copper and derivative products. Pending: Section 232 Investigation.
*   **Global:** Lumber ‚Äì potential tariffs on imports of timber, lumber, and their derivative products. Pending ‚Äì Section 232 Investigation.
*   **Global:** 100% tariff on movies produced outside of the United States. Proposed: 5/4/2025, announced by President Trump on Truth Social.
*   **E.U.:** 25% ad valorem duty on all products of the E.U. Proposed: 2/26/2025, superseded by Reciprocal Tariffs.

title: 5Trump Rails Against Court Rulings Blocking His Tariffs,...
content: President Donald Trump claimed losing legal challenges to his sweeping tariffs would lead to the "economic ruination" of America after federal courts blocked his emergency trade powers while an ...
resumen:
President Donald Trump claimed losing legal challenges to his sweeping tariffs would lead to the ‚Äúeconomic ruination‚Äù of America.

Trump warned on Truth Social Sunday that adverse court rulings ‚Äúwould allow other Countries to hold our Nation hostage with their anti-American Tariffs,‚Äù following the U.S. Court of International Trade‚Äôs unanimous decision blocking emergency import taxes.

The U.S. Court of International Trade ruled unanimously to block Trump‚Äôs use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose tariffs.

Judges appointed by Trump, Barack Obama, and Ronald Reagan said the administration overstepped constitutional limits.

U.S. District Judge Rudolph Contreras issued a separate ruling blocking emergency tariff powers, writing in a 33-page document that IEEPA ‚Äúdoes not grant Trump the authority to impose or adjust tariffs without approval from Congress.‚Äù

The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted a temporary stay on Thursday, delaying the lower court‚Äôs ruling.

Trump administration lawyers have until June 9 to file their response.

Reciprocal tariffs announced April 2 remain in legal limbo.

The blocked tariffs include 10% across-the-board duties, 20% on Chinese imports, and 25% on non-USMCA goods from Canada and Mexico, potentially generating $200 billion annually.

Goldman Sachs analysts noted Trump could reimpose similar tariffs ‚Äúwithin days‚Äù using Section 122 trade law, which allows 15% tariffs for 150 days without congressional approval.

The S&P 500 rose 0.6% Thursday following the court decision.

Cato Institute economist Scott Lincicome said import-dependent sectors rallied on relief from ‚Äúpotentially crippling new costs.‚Äù

The original tariff announcement in April triggered a $5 trillion market capitalization loss over two days.

title: Dividend disaster? Maybe not.
content: First, the bill still needs to be passed by the Senate and signed into law by President Trump so it‚Äôs not a 100% done deal. Some US senators are opposing the ‚ÄòOne, Big, Beautiful Bill‚Äô, which is ...
resumen: In the US tax bill called the One, Big, Beautiful Bill, a new section will potentially increase withholding taxes on US dividend income for Canadian investors. Currently, in non-registered cash accounts, Canadian investors incur a 15% withholding tax on all US dividend income. The proposed tax bill would see the withholding tax rate increase from 15% to 20% effective January 1, 2026, and then increase 5% per year to a max of 50%. Interest income from US bond investments will be excluded, with the focus on US dividends. If the bill is passed this will reduce dividend income and overall returns for Canadian investors. The US government is saying this is in retaliation against unfair ‚Äòdiscriminatory‚Äô taxes against US companies, like Canada‚Äôs recently implemented digital service taxes (DST) where Canada now charges large technology companies like Facebook a 3% annual tax. The bill still needs to be passed by the Senate and signed into law by President Trump. This potential increase in withholding tax is only applicable to non-registered accounts. Any dividends received from US investments in registered accounts like RSPs are not impacted. The dividend yield for the S&P 500 is only around 1% these days.

title: Court Orders Threaten President Trump‚Äôs Tariff Regime
content: The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit consolidated and temporarily stayed the first decision from the ...
resumen:
On June 2, 2025, the article discusses court orders that threaten President Trump‚Äôs tariff regime.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit consolidated and temporarily stayed the first decision from the U.S. Court of International Trade (USCIT). This temporary stay keeps the tariffs in effect and will likely last until at least June 9, 2025. At that point the Federal Circuit will determine whether to issue a longer stay. The second order out of DC is stayed by the issuing judge for 14 days from issuance.

On May 28, the U.S. Court of International Trade (USCIT) unanimously issued a permanent injunction blocking enforcement of the Trump administration‚Äôs 10% ‚Äúbaseline‚Äù tariff, higher country-specific ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariffs and the additional ‚Äúfentanyl‚Äù tariffs imposed under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA, 50 U.S. Code ¬ß 1701), and ordered the administration to rescind the relevant executive orders within 10 days.

On May 29, Judge Rudolph Contreras of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia issued a preliminary injunction restricting the administration from imposing IEEPA-based tariffs on two specific plaintiffs, Learning Resources, Inc. and hand2mind, Inc.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit temporarily stayed the USCIT decision‚Äîkeeping the tariffs in effect. The appeals court set a deadline of June 5 for responses to the government‚Äôs motion for a longer stay, making it likely that the temporary stay will remain in effect until at least June 9, 2025.

The two court orders do not affect the tariffs imposed on specific sectors including steel, aluminum and autos under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962. These will remain in effect regardless of how this legal process plays out. The orders will also not impact the sector-specific tariffs that the Trump administration is expected to impose under Section 232 in the near future on pharmaceuticals, critical minerals and semiconductors/smartphones. Finally, they do not impact the tariffs imposed on China under Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 during President Trump‚Äôs first term.

The USCIT ruled on whether the president may invoke IEEPA to impose unlimited broad-based tariffs on imports by declaring trade deficits or related economic concerns as a ‚Äúnational emergency.‚Äù The Trump administration invoked IEEPA to impose a series of broad tariffs, including a general 10% ‚Äúbaseline‚Äù tariff, higher country-specific reciprocal tariffs and additional fentanyl tariffs targeting imports from China, Mexico and Canada.

Plaintiffs, which included private businesses and a coalition of U.S. states, challenged President Trump‚Äôs novel use of IEEPA to impose broad-based tariffs.

The USCIT‚Äôs three-judge panel held that President Trump exceeded his delegated authority under IEEPA while also finding that the president may invoke IEEPA to impose tariffs with specific limitations. First, tariffs imposed under IEEPA must be limited in scope and duration. Second, tariffs imposed under IEEPA must be directly tied to the specific ‚Äúunusual and extraordinary threat‚Äù for which the national emergency was declared.

The USCIT held that when tariffs are geared towards correcting trade imbalances, the proper statutory regime is the Trade Act of 1974 (Pub. L. No. 93-618, ¬ß 122), rather than IEEPA. Section 122 specifically authorizes the president to impose temporary tariffs or quotas‚Äîof up to 15% and for a maximum of 150 days‚Äîwhen the United States faces ‚Äúlarge and serious‚Äù balance-of-payments deficits or other fundamental international payments problems.

The implications of the USCIT‚Äôs ruling on existing tariffs are:
*   **10% Baseline Tariff:** An across-the-board 10% tariff went into effect for goods from most countries on April 5 and remained in place even after plans to impose a country-specific reciprocal tariff regime on April 9 were paused. Goods from Canada and Mexico are not subject to the 10% baseline tariff. This tariff exceeded IEEPA‚Äôs delegation of authority because it lacked ‚Äúidentifiable limits‚Äù and was not tied to a specific emergency.
*   **Country-Specific Reciprocal Tariffs:** These tariffs are imposed at varying rates on most nations and are intended to correct long-standing trade deficits, effective April 9. These tariffs were paused before going into effect, with the exception of China. On May 14, the 125% ‚Äúreciprocal‚Äù tariff on Chinese goods was also paused until Aug. 12, 2025. These tariffs are geared towards correcting long-standing trade deficits, which the USCIT held was outside of IEEPA‚Äôs scope.
*   **Fentanyl Tariffs:** On Feb. 1, President Trump declared that the importation of fentanyl poses a national security threat. A 25% tariff is in effect until further notice on goods from Canada and Mexico that fail to satisfy United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) rules of origin or that claim and qualify for USMCA preference. Canadian energy resources that fail to satisfy USMCA preference, specifically potash, are subject to a 10% tariff. In addition, a 20% tariff is in effect on all Chinese goods. These tariffs fail to directly ‚Äúdeal with‚Äù the threat posed by the influx of fentanyl importations because there is no ‚Äúdirect link between \[the] act and the problem it purports to address.‚Äù

The following tariffs are not affected by the USCIT ruling and are still in effect:
*   Section 232 Tariffs: Sector-specific ‚Äúreshoring‚Äù tariffs on strategic goods including the 25% tariff on steel, aluminum and automobiles imposed under Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962.
*   Section 301 Tariffs: Tariffs on certain goods from China imposed during Trump‚Äôs first term, authorized under the Trade Act of 1974.

Senior Counselor to the President for Trade and Manufacturing Peter Navarro maintained that the national trade deficit and importation of fentanyl threatens national security. He argued the White House has a ‚Äústrong case,‚Äù noting the CIT ‚Äúbasically said we‚Äôre right‚Äîjust use different rules and laws.‚Äù Navarro cited Section 122 as a possible authority that the administration may use in the interim to maintain tariffs while the appeals process moves forward. He also noted Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974; Section 232 of the Trade Expansion Act of 1962 and Section 338 of the Tariff Act of 1930 as other possible avenues to maintain the tariff regime.

title: Carney won't reveal spending plans, enraging critics ‚Äî but some call it savvy
content: The government is defending its decision not to issue a spring budget by pointing to the uncertain economic situation. While not all critics accept that framing, some say there could be some benefits ...
resumen:
Prime Minister Mark Carney won't release a federal budget before fall, which would mean over a year since the government released one, an unprecedented gap (outside of 2020).
Interim Conservative leader Andrew Scheer and others in his party asked the budget question repeatedly.
Carney pointed out that Pierre Polievre‚Äôs 100-day plan announced during the election hadn‚Äôt included a budget either.
Carney and his finance minister, Fran√ßois-Philippe Champagne, took turns repeating the great news that they were delivering a tax cut and breaking down provincial trade barriers.
Carney gave reporters the closest thing he‚Äôs given to an explanation for skipping the spring budget in Rome: ‚ÄúThere's not much value in trying to rush through a budget in a very narrow window ‚Äî three weeks ‚Äî with a new cabinet [and] effectively a new finance minister," he said. "We will have a much more comprehensive, effective, ambitious, prudent budget in the fall.‚Äù
In an interview with Power and Politics, Carney said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not a fan of picking an arbitrary number and then figuring out how to spend up to it,‚Äù after describing a host of uncertainties looming over Canada‚Äôs defence budget. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs one of the reasons we will have a fall budget, not a budget tomorrow.‚Äù
NDP MP Heather McPherson said that it‚Äôs baffling why Carney invited such a storm.
Finance minister Champagne told Politico that the reason Liberals are waiting until fall is they want to have ‚Äúmore clarity around defense, around the trade war that is happening now in the world,‚Äù referring to tariffs and the upcoming NATO meeting where Canada‚Äôs defence budget is almost certain to rise dramatically.
Champagne said the government is also waiting to get ‚Äúinitial feedback from our initiatives on government efficiency.‚Äù
Michael Wernick, former Clerk of the Privy Council, doesn't believe the delay affects the business of the government and may improve scrutiny from parliament.
Wernick said: ‚ÄúIn practical or operational terms, the four-month delay really doesn't matter.‚Äù
Wernick said: ‚ÄúThe practice of having a big, beautiful budget, chock full of just about everything the government wants to do in the coming year and hundreds of pages of implementation legislation covering everything from A to Z, is a fairly recent practice.‚Äù
The day-to-day business of a government doesn‚Äôt depend on a budget.
One example is the 1 per cent tax cut Carney has promised to Canadians in the lowest income bracket.
Over the past two decades, Wernick explained, governments of both parties have tended to jam their entire year‚Äôs goals into a single budget.
Ian Lee, an associate professor in the Spratt School of Business at Carleton University, said that it reduces transparency and confidence in the government.
Christopher Ragan, founding director of the Max Bell School of Public Policy, said that if you want a well-informed debate about spending, especially in the world of a minority government, we should probably know what the books look like.
Michael Wernick said: ‚ÄúThe Department of Finance puts out something called the fiscal monitor every month.‚Äù
Michael Wernick said that if parliament wants more recent or granular information, they just call the minister of finance in front of the finance committee.
Heather McPherson said that the advantage for them is they don't want to have a bad budget that they have to go out on the barbecue scene with.
Ian Lee said that Carney‚Äôs strategic objective is to buy himself a little bit of time.
Michael Wernick takes what Carney said in Rome, and what Champagne told Politico, at face value.
A press secretary told that the best bet for a concise quote from Carney is his Rome statement.

title: Letter: Trump tariffs, trade deals bearing fruit
content: Reading the hate letters about President Trump makes me wonder if the writers really understand the difference between opinions filled with anger ...
resumen: Editor: Reading the hate letters about President Trump makes me wonder if the writers really understand the difference between opinions filled with anger hoping that President Trump fails versus the facts. Their hope is that inflation, job losses and prices rise and the stock market sinks. The exact opposite has been true since Jan. 20. I filled my gas tank the other day for $2.99 per gallon. Most people can‚Äôt define what a tariff specifically is or does. A tariff attempts to level the playing field for hardworking Americans instead of taking advantage of them. With regard to immigrants, President Trump has always and will always welcome them to this great country of ours as long as they enter legally. Trade deals secured by President Trump have already been helping America prosper. Significant progress has been made in many areas of the world. As my mom told me ‚ÄúTalk is cheap when not backed up with substance.‚Äù President Trump has endeavored to do for America exactly as he promised during the campaign. Phil Spinka, South Abington Twp.

title: Asian markets rise as US stock indexes near records amid easing trade tensions
content: Shares rose early Tuesday in Asia after U.S. stock indexes drifted closer to records, while oil prices extended gains. Beijing and Washington dialed back trade friction as the U.S. extended exemptions ...
resumen:
Shares rose early Tuesday in Asia after U.S. stock indexes drifted closer to records, while oil prices extended gains.

Beijing and Washington dialed back trade friction as the U.S. extended exemptions for tariffs on some Chinese goods, including solar manufacturing equipment, that U.S. industries rely on for their own production. The U.S. Trade Representative extended those exemptions, which were due to expire on May 31, by three months through Aug. 31.

China criticized the U.S. on Monday over moves it alleged harmed Chinese interests, including issuing AI chip export control guidelines, stopping the sale of chip design software to China, and planning to revoke Chinese student visas.

Hong Kong‚Äôs Hang Seng gained 1.1% to 23,417.39, while the Shanghai Composite index added 0.3% to 3,356.36.

In Tokyo, the Nikkei 225 advanced 0.6% to 37,683.19.

Australia‚Äôs S&P/ASX 200 was up 0.7% to 8,475.50.

In Taiwan, the Taiex gained 1.4%.

On Monday, U.S. stock indexes drifted closer to their records following a stellar May, Wall Street‚Äôs best month since 2023. The S&P 500 rose 0.4% to 5,935.94. The Dow Jones Industrial Average added 0.1% to 42,305.48. The Nasdaq composite climbed 0.7% to 19,242.61.

Indexes had fallen close to 1% in the morning following some discouraging updates on U.S. manufacturing.

President Donald Trump has been warning that U.S. businesses and households could feel some pain as he tries to use tariffs to bring more manufacturing jobs back to the country, and their on-and-off rollout has created lots of uncertainty.

Nvidia climbed 1.7%, and Meta Platforms rose 3.6%.

Oil prices have gained as attacks by Ukraine in Russia raise uncertainty about the flow of oil and gas around the world. Early Tuesday, U.S. benchmark crude oil was up 62 cents at $63.14 per barrel. Brent crude, the international standard, picked up 57 cents to $65.19 per barrel.

Markets took in stride fresh salvos between the world‚Äôs two largest economies, just a few weeks after the United States and China had agreed to pause many of their tariffs that had threatened to drag the economy into a recession.

Trump on Friday told Pennsylvania steelworkers he‚Äôs doubling the tariff on steel imports to 50% to protect their industry.

Nucor jumped 10.1%, and Steel Dynamics rallied 10.3%.

Ford fell 3.9%, and General Motors reversed by 3.9%.

Lyra Therapeutics soared nearly 311%.

In the bond market, Treasury yields rose as worries continue about how much debt the U.S. government will pile on due to plans to cut taxes and increase the deficit.

The yield on the 10-year Treasury climbed to 4.44% from 4.41% late Friday and from just 4.01% roughly two months ago.

Yields had dipped briefly in the morning, before rallying back, following the updates on manufacturing, which suggested that effects of Trump‚Äôs tariffs are taking root in the economy.

A report from S&P Global on manufacturing came in better than expected.

The dollar rose to 143.10 Japanese yen from 142.71 yen. The euro slipped to $1.1438 from $1.1443.

title: Trump 'revenge tax' may open new front in global trade war, with consequences for your wallet
content: A little-noticed provision in President Donald Trump's sweeping tax and spending bill could spark the next battle in an escalating global trade war - and potentially unnerve an already rattled market ...
resumen:
The One Big Beautiful Bill Act passed by the House of Representatives in May included a provision called Section 899, which would authorize the White House to impose a "revenge tax" on foreign owners of U.S. assets, including Treasury bonds.

Chye-Ching Huang, executive director of the Tax Policy Center at New York University School of Law, said in a statement that the House bill leaves uncertainty about whether it would subject certain foreign holdings of U.S. Treasurys to its so-called 'revenge' or 'retaliatory' tax, and that this tax might even apply to foreign government holdings of U.S. Treasury bonds.

Analysts warn that if foreign central banks or sovereign wealth funds believe their Treasury holdings could be subject to taxation, it could dampen demand for U.S. debt at a time when the government is borrowing at historic levels and interest rates remain stubbornly high.

Morgan Stanley credit strategist Michael Zezas wrote in a Monday note to clients that even the perception that the tax might apply to U.S. government debt could result in a shift in demand away from Treasurys to other assets.

The yield on the 10-year U.S. Treasury bond has risen from about 3.7% to 4.5%.

Bill Dudley, former president of the New York Fed, wrote in a Friday opinion piece in Bloomberg, that America is becoming less attractive to global investors at a time when its government needs them more than ever.

Karen Petrou, managing partner at Federal Financial Analytics, warns that Section 899 may signal something far more consequential than a targeted trade response, reflecting a broader Trump-era shift toward economic nationalism.

In a Monday note to clients, she cited recent commentary by onetime Trump Fed board nominee Judy Shelton, who has criticized payments the Fed makes to foreign banks on the reserves they have deposited at the U.S. central bank.

Petrou predicted that the Trump administration could soon cast these payments as giveaways to foreigners, even though they are a key pillar in the global dollar system, ensuring "dollar-clearing stability in a crisis."

Petrou argued that more such moves should be expected in the future.

Supporters of the measure argue that it's a necessary tool to use against governments seeking to tax U.S. companies through digital-service levies and other policies. They also argue that the law won't allow taxes on U.S. Treasury bonds but would be used instead to tax foreign multinational profits earned in the U.S. and sent abroad.

Morgan Stanley's Zezas wrote that the intent of this tax law is that it will never be applied, and that "conventional wisdom" is that it won't allow taxes on Treasury bonds, though there will be a big push to tweak the language in the Senate to make this plain before sending the bill to the president's desk.

Analysts at Beacon Policy Advisors wrote in a Monday note that while it's possible it could "be modified in the Senate, it's worth noting" that the measure "is widely supported by GOP senators, suggesting that the effort to strip [it] from the bill will be an uphill battle."

title: Trump tariffs have cost businesses more than $34 billion in losses
content: You can double or triple your tally and we‚Äôd still say ... the magnitude is bound to be far greater than most people realize,‚Äù said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld ...
resumen:
Trump tariffs have cost businesses more than $34 billion in losses.

Trump‚Äôs trade war has cost companies more than $34 billion in lost sales and higher costs, according to a Reuters analysis of corporate disclosures.

Major U.S. tech firms such as Apple, Amazon, and Microsoft collectively lost over $760 billion in market capitalization in one day.

The S&P 500 plunged 4.8%, erasing around $2.5 trillion in value, marking the steepest drop since 2020.

Companies including Apple, Ford, Porsche and Sony have reportedly pulled or slashed their profit forecasts.

Reuters reviewed company statements, regulatory filings, conference and media call transcripts to pull together for the first time a snapshot of the tariff cost so far for global businesses.

title: Texas and Mexico‚Äôs Economic Integration Again Faces Uncertain Future
content: The Trump administration‚Äôs tariff posturing has created uncertainty that could reverse decades of economic growth on both sides of the border.
resumen: In the November 2018 issue of D CEO, we wrote about our ‚ÄúTexico‚Äù research project. We coined the name, combining Texas and Mexico, to describe the rapid integration of neighboring economies freed from trade barriers. Greater economic freedom spurred business activity. Texas-Mexico trade soared, led by inputs used in cross-border production. Companies from all over the world invested in Texico, lowering production costs in Mexico and establishing U.S. bases in Texas. Market forces forged elaborate supply chains, increasing efficiency. No state gained more from Mexico‚Äôs market opening than Texas. It was partly a matter of geography‚Äîa 1,254-mile border with the busiest road and rail crossings. Texas also offered its neighbor a big, diverse, capital-rich economic partner looking for new business opportunities. Our Texico report highlighted the gains on both sides of the Rio Grande, but that wasn‚Äôt what prompted us to write it. We worried about Texico‚Äôs uncertain future. Businesses on both sides of the border did most of the heavy lifting in creating Texico. However, it took broad policies supporting economic freedom to set cross-border economic integration into motion. Writing in 2018, we saw signs of trouble in the erosion of political support for open trade. Donald Trump swept into the White House in 2016, taking potshots at Mexico and the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Two years later, Mexico elected Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, a populist and economic nationalist, as president. We warned that the two elections revealed chillier views about the benefits of open economies. Could they produce new waves of protectionism and regulation that would reverse the Texico partnership? Trump didn‚Äôt scuttle NAFTA. Instead, North America‚Äôs three countries renegotiated NAFTA and signed the U.S.-Mexico-Canada Agreement in 2019. Trump lost the election the next year. Obrador signed the new deal, too, allaying fears about changing the Mexican economy‚Äôs external orientation through the end of his term in 2024. Setting aside the pandemic year of 2020, policy stability on both sides of the border kept business humming, and the integration of the Texas-Mexico economic space continued. Last year, for example, Texas‚Äô Mexican sales of $123.4 billion represented 27 percent of its total exports, compared with $92 billion in 2016. We were quite happy our dismal scenario didn‚Äôt play out. We never expected to revisit it. But here we are. As in 2018, we‚Äôre once again worried Texico faces an uncertain future‚Äîfor the same reason. In January, Trump returned to the presidency, still breathing fire about trade with other countries being bad for America. It defies economic logic, but Trump believes a bilateral trade deficit means a country is robbing the U.S. The offenders in 2024 include Mexico at $171.8 billion and Canada at $63.3 billion. Trump has long believed in tariffs as a panacea for America‚Äôs chronic trade deficits, and he campaigned on a promise to act. And he did. In January, the architect of the USMCA brushed aside the treaty and announced 25 percent tariffs on Mexico and Canada‚Äîbut offered a brief reprieve. Then came 25 percent tariffs on steel, aluminum, automobiles, and auto parts. April brought a new reciprocal tariff regime that imposed the highest tariff rates in U.S. history. All countries will pay 10 percent, but rates of over 25 percent will be applied to dozens of countries. In good news, Mexico emerged relatively unscathed because of USMCA rules. It still faces tariffs on cars, steel, and aluminum, but many goods will still be tariff-free, including avocados and other agricultural goods, textiles, garments, and pharmaceuticals. Mexico still has plenty to worry about even with USMCA protections. The April tariffs sent immediate shockwaves through the global economy. With the world facing the first global trade war since the Great Depression, stock markets plunged, consumer confidence faltered, and forecasters warned of inflation and possible recession this year. A trade war and global recession would drag Mexico‚Äôs U.S.-dependent economy down with it. Its big, diverse economy gives Texas some cushion against troubles south of the Rio Grande, but a tariff war will bring pain. Texas exports far more than any other state, and Mexico is its top trading partner. If trade barriers split the Texico economic space, the Texas companies and workers who make up the North American supply chains and the consumers who benefit from their production will be among the first to feel the tariffs‚Äô bad effects‚Äîlost jobs and higher prices. Trump has wavered and retreated, but he hasn‚Äôt let go of his fascination with tariffs. Texico will remain under a cloud. There‚Äôs precedent for stepping back from the brink. The partnership escaped first-term Trump relatively unscathed, thanks to cooler heads and the USMCA. This time around, another deal might emerge. Texico is too good an idea to lose, and Texans and Mexicans need to fight for it. They have invested three decades in building the infrastructure and business relationships that support economic growth on both sides of the border. They‚Äôll continue to reap the benefits for a long time to come. Adam Smith, the father of modern economics, taught us that trade makes nations richer. Shutting down trade with tariffs and other restraints will make us poorer. When it comes to tariffs, the goal should be reducing them, not increasing them, making trade more, not less, open. That was the goal of NAFTA, and it worked wonders to increase wealth in Texico. Why go in the opposite direction? W. Michael Cox is professor of economics in the Bridwell Institute for Economic Freedom at Southern Methodist University‚Äôs Cox School of Business. Richard Alm is writer-in-residence at the Bridwell Institute.

title: At this Prairie Village toy store, the trickiest puzzles are Trump's tariffs on China
content: China is the source of 80% of toys purchased in the U.S. Two business owners in Kansas have been forced by the president's barrage of trade barriers to buy product early and in bulk, and deal with ...
resumen:
At a Prairie Village toy store, the trickiest puzzles are Trump's tariffs on China.
China is the source of 80% of toys purchased in the U.S.
Brett Goodwin and Alan Tipton, owners of The Learning Tree toy store, have been forced by the president's trade barriers to buy product early and in bulk, and deal with supply-chain issues.
Trump imposed, withdrew and doubled down on import taxes.
Goodwin said they had to rush to secure stock.
On Wednesday, Tipton and Goodwin said their response to tariffs was to purchase extra merchandise and make business commitments earlier than normal in an attempt to build warehouse stock.
Some invoices contained a tariff surcharge of 10%.
Tipton said consumer interest in toy store merchandise remained solid despite the potential influence of tariffs on purchasing behavior.
Goodwin and Tipton gave U.S. Rep. Sharice Davids, D-Kansas, a tour of the store.
Davids said she wanted to learn firsthand how small businesses responded to Trump's tariffs.
Her hosts said Congress should pass a tariff exemption for toys.
Last month, Davids received a letter from Goodwin echoing the American Specialty Toy Retailer Association's concern regarding tariffs and the impact they'd have on small businesses and consumer prices.
Davids said she was alarmed Trump asserted U.S. children should become accustomed to owning two dolls rather than 30 if tariffs increased store prices.
Trump temporarily reduced the U.S. tariff on Chinese goods from 145% to 30%.
Davids said children in the United States were at the mercy of tariffs in terms of birthday or holiday gifts.
Davids said the United States had an opportunity to expand domestic manufacturing, but the president's "on-again, off-again, tumultuous, reckless approach" to international trade wasn't helping businesses make strategic decisions about business expansion.

title: The Real-World Impact Of Tariffs: What Businesses And Consumers Should Know
content: Ultimately, those who respond with flexibility and foresight‚Äîwhether businesses or consumers‚Äîwill be best positioned to handle the pressures of a tariff-driven economy.
resumen:
In the first half of 2024, President Donald Trump imposed numerous tariffs, raising import taxes on a broad range of goods. Economists and investors are scrutinizing the potential impacts of these tariffs on U.S. inflation and how they could complicate the Federal Reserve‚Äôs plans for the latter half of the year.

For business leaders, this means navigating a new era of higher input costs, disrupted supply chains and pricing uncertainty. Companies must rapidly reassess sourcing strategies, renegotiate supplier terms and consider whether‚Äîand how‚Äîto pass added costs onto customers without losing competitive edge.

For consumers, the consequences are just as real. Prices on everyday goods are expected to rise, from electronics to groceries to automobiles. Managing household budgets, delaying major purchases or switching to domestic alternatives may become necessary in the face of imported inflation.

Tariffs act like taxes on imports, and businesses typically pass these extra costs to consumers, leading to higher prices. With Trump‚Äôs broad tariffs affecting goods from raw materials to electronics, inflation could rise sharply. By April, early data showed import prices had been tame before the tariffs went into effect. Markets see broad tariffs as a supply shock: raising costs while potentially weakening growth by disrupting trade. Even the Federal Reserve‚Äôs own analysts have flagged this risk. Minutes from the Fed‚Äôs late-March meeting showed "policymakers were nearly unanimous that the economy faced risks of simultaneously higher inflation and slower growth, commonly referred to as stagflation."

American consumers are likely to feel the bite of tariffs in their wallets. With such wide-ranging import taxes, everyday items may become more expensive in the coming months. Consumers are likely to face rising prices on a wide range of goods, from food and clothing to electronics and furniture, due to tariffs. Even U.S.-made products could become more expensive if they depend on imported parts. Notably, auto prices may climb sharply, as a tariff on imported vehicles and components affects both foreign and domestically assembled cars.

For businesses, this environment demands agility and transparency. To offset rising input costs, companies should explore:
‚Ä¢	Supplier diversification, including sourcing from countries with lower tariff exposure or leveraging domestic manufacturers where viable.
‚Ä¢	Cost reengineering, such as redesigning products to reduce dependence on high-tariff components.
‚Ä¢	Automation and productivity gains, which can absorb some cost pressures without passing them to the consumer.

On the consumer side, adapting to tariff-driven inflation may require more mindful financial planning. Households could:
‚Ä¢	Delay discretionary purchases, especially for imported goods like electronics or furniture, to wait for potential price stabilization or find domestic alternatives.
‚Ä¢	Shift to local brands where prices may be more stable or where producers haven't yet factored in steep import-related costs.
‚Ä¢	Track loyalty programs or bulk-buy opportunities, particularly for durable goods and staple imports that might face steady price increases.

The Federal Reserve now faces a serious policy dilemma going into the second half of 2025. Prior to the tariff announcements, the economic backdrop was relatively favorable‚Äîinflation had been gradually easing toward the Fed‚Äôs 2% target, and unemployment was low. The tariffs threaten to upend this ‚ÄúGoldilocks‚Äù scenario by injecting an inflationary shock even as they dampen growth prospects. Fed Chair Jerome Powell has acknowledged that Trump‚Äôs tariffs are larger than expected, likely leading to higher inflation and slower growth than anticipated. In other words, the Fed‚Äôs dual mandate objectives‚Äîstable prices and maximum employment‚Äîare being pulled in opposite directions by the trade policies. Powell noted that it is too soon to know the exact right policy response, emphasizing the high uncertainty around the outlook.

Businesses and consumers must stay strategic and resilient. Companies should start by assessing their exposure to tariffs‚Äîidentifying affected suppliers and exploring domestic or lower-tariff alternatives. As prices rise, clear communication becomes essential. Firms that explain the economic reasons behind price changes are more likely to maintain customer trust. At the same time, improving efficiency through logistics, automation and streamlined operations can help offset some of the impact. Consumers, too, will need to adapt. Prioritizing essentials, postponing nonurgent purchases and choosing local alternatives can help manage higher costs. Thoughtful budgeting and planning ahead will also be key to preserving purchasing power.

title: U.S. Dependence on China for Rare Earth Magnets Is Causing Shortages
content: The United States allowed its rare earth metals industry to move to China and could now face severe economic disruption as China limits crucial supplies.
resumen: Two decades ago, factories in Indiana that turned rare earth metals into magnets moved production to China. The United States is now reckoning with the cost of losing that supply chain. The Chinese government abruptly halted exports of rare earth magnets to any country on April 4 as part of its trade war with the United States. American officials had expected that China would relax its restrictions on the magnets as part of the trade truce the two countries reached in mid-May. On Friday, President Trump suggested that China had continued to limit access. American and European companies are running out of the magnets. American automakers are the hardest hit, with executives warning that production at factories across the Midwest and South could be cut back in the coming days and weeks. Carmakers need the magnets for the electric motors that run brakes, steering and fuel injectors. The motors in a single luxury car seat, for example, use as many as 12 magnets. Factory robots depend on rare earth magnets, too. Nazak Nikakhtar, who was the assistant secretary of commerce overseeing export controls during Mr. Trump‚Äôs first term, said, ‚ÄúThis is America‚Äôs, and the world‚Äôs, Achilles‚Äô heel, which China continuously exploits.‚Äù The Chinese government has said little lately about its rare earth export restrictions. Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, said on ABC‚Äôs ‚ÄúThis Week‚Äù on Sunday that Mr. Trump and China‚Äôs leader, Xi Jinping, could speak about trade as soon as this week, though no date had been set. After China stopped all exports, it said future shipments would require separate export licenses. China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce has struggled since then to issue licenses. It gave a handful to European companies in mid-April and a few more for American companies last week, but world supplies are dwindling fast. Jens Eskelund, the president of the European Union Chamber of Commerce in China, said, ‚ÄúThere are a few approvals coming through, but they are far from being sufficient to prevent imminent production halts. We are still facing a major disruption of supply chains.‚Äù Some Chinese rare earth magnet makers have stopped producing while waiting for permission to resume exports. The weekslong gap in magnet production is moving through supply chains and may soon reach manufacturers. Michael Dunne, an automotive consultant specializing in China, said, ‚ÄúChina could bring America‚Äôs automotive assembly plants to a standstill.‚Äù China produces 90 percent of the world‚Äôs nearly 200,000 tons a year of high-performance rare earth magnets. Japanese companies produce most of the rest in Japan and Vietnam, mainly for Japanese manufacturers. The United States produces practically none, although small factories will start full production this year in South Carolina and Texas. Worldwide sales of mined rare earths total only $5 billion a year. China has a formidable competitive advantage. The state-owned industry has few environmental compliance costs for its mines and an almost unlimited government budget for building huge processing refineries and magnet factories. China refines over 99 percent of the world‚Äôs supply of so-called heavy rare earths. Heavy rare earths are essential for making magnets that can resist the high temperatures and electrical fields found in cars, semiconductors and many other technologies. The sole American rare earths mine, in Mountain Pass, Calif., stopped producing in 1998. A $1 billion Pentagon-backed investment program followed in 2010. MP Materials, a Chicago investor group that included a minority partner company partly owned by the Chinese government, bought the mine in 2017. The mine reopened the next year, but shipped its ore to China for the difficult task of separating the various kinds of rare earths. Only in recent months has the mine become able to chemically separate the rare earths in more than half its output. MP Materials built the new factory in Texas that will turn separated rare earths into magnets. A considerable bottleneck lies in transforming separated rare earths into chemically pure metal ingots that can be fed into the furnaces of magnet-making machines. A New England start-up, Phoenix Tailings, is addressing that shortcoming. Phoenix Tailings has four machines each the size of a small cottage at its factory in Burlington, Mass. Each one produces a 6.6-pound ingot every three hours around the clock. The operation‚Äôs overall capacity is 40 tons a year. Nick Myers, Phoenix‚Äôs chief executive, declined to identify the buyer but said it was an automotive company. Phoenix is installing equipment at a larger site in Exeter, N.H., to produce metal at a rate of 200 tons a year. Thomas Villal√≥n Jr., Phoenix‚Äôs chief technical officer, said ramping up production quickly was important during a trade war: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a race right now.‚Äù

title: A rate cut debate is heating up inside the Fed
content: A divide is emerging within the Fed about whether to hold rates steady or start to get more comfortable about cuts later this year as officials try to determine if any inflation coming from President ...
resumen:
A divide is emerging within the Federal Reserve about whether to hold rates steady for some time or get more comfortable about cuts later this year as officials try to determine whether any inflation coming from President Trump's tariffs will prove to be longer-lasting.

Some policymakers are arguing for "looking through" the impact of the duties as temporary, a stance that would leave the door open for cuts. Many on the rate-setting committee, however, believe there is a risk that inflation from tariffs could become more persistent.

Federal Reserve governor Chris Waller is now firmly in the first camp. On Sunday night, he made another argument for why any impact on inflation from tariffs likely won't last.

Waller said in a speech in Seoul, South Korea: "Given my belief that any tariff-induced inflation will not be persistent and that inflation expectations are anchored, I support looking through any tariff effects on near-term inflation when setting the policy rate."

Waller stressed that a strong job market and progress on inflation through April offer additional time to see how trade negotiations play out and the economy evolves.

He does see a scenario in which he would support "good news" rate cuts later this year if inflation continues to make progress toward the Fed's 2% goal, the job market remains solid, and the effective tariff rate settles close to his new outlook of 15%.

Chicago Fed president Austan Goolsbee also said Monday that uncertainty around tariffs is creating what he called some "dirt in the air," but ‚ÄúI still think underneath there we basically are on that path" for lower rates.

Other members of the Fed ‚Äî including Minneapolis Fed president Neel Kashkari and Dallas Fed president Lorie Logan ‚Äî have been more vocal about holding rates steady.

Kashkari said last week that he believes trade talks could take months or years to resolve and that tariff increases could occur tit for tat as trading partners respond to one another.

Thus, he wants to hold rates steady "until there is more clarity on the path for tariffs and their impact on prices."

Logan sent a strong veiled message last week about holding rates steady in the face of Trump's calls to lower them.

She said rates are in a "good place" now and that it could take "quite some time to know whether the balance of risks is shifting in one direction or another."

She added that the effects of rate changes take time to play out, and to get the balance right, the Fed needs to think about where the economy is headed, not just where it is now.

Logan said: "In the short run, a central bank could always juice employment by cutting interest rates. People might enjoy that for a little while. But over time, excessive rate cuts would trigger a spiral of inflation."

She reiterated Monday in Dallas that there are risks to both side of the Fed's mandate for stable prices and full employment and that "monetary policy is really well positioned for us to wait and be patient and watch the data knowing that if the risks are to materially change on either side, we're well positioned to act."

According to the Fed minutes from the central bank's May policy meeting released last week, some officials thought tariffs on intermediate goods ‚Äî parts used to make products, like steel or aluminum ‚Äî could contribute to a more persistent increase in inflation.

Trump announced on Friday that he will double tariffs on steel and aluminum imports to 50% from 25%.

A few officials at the last meeting thought supply chain disruptions caused by tariffs could also have longer-lasting effects on inflation, reminiscent of such effects during the pandemic.

Waller said Sunday that he expects the effects on inflation to be temporary and most apparent in the second half of 2025.

He noted that it will hinge on the ultimate size of the increase and on how exporters and importers respond.

Waller thinks any inflation from tariffs will prove fleeting because there is no shortage of workers as there was during the pandemic, there's no indication right now that tariffs are causing big disruptions in supply chains, and there's no giant government stimulus as there was during COVID.

He noted that there was very little evidence of trade policies' effects on inflation or the economy through April, but that may change in the coming weeks.

Waller said: "As of today, I see downside risks to economic activity and employment and upside risks to inflation in the second half of 2025, but how these risks evolve is strongly tied to how trade policy evolves."

title: China Rejects Trump‚Äôs Accusation That It Violated Trade Truce
content: In response to President Trump‚Äôs claim, China said the United States was the one introducing a series of ‚Äúdiscriminatory restrictive measures.‚Äù ...
resumen:
China said on Monday that the United States had ‚Äúseverely undermined‚Äù the trade truce the two countries reached last month, striking back against President Trump‚Äôs accusations that it was violating the terms of their agreement.

China‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce called Mr. Trump‚Äôs attacks on social media last week ‚Äúbaseless.‚Äù He had accused Beijing of failing to live up to its end of their trade deal, a 90-day rollback of tariffs and other trade barriers to give the two countries more time to negotiate and prevent an all-out trade war.

China‚Äôs commerce ministry said it had continued to honor its agreement responsibly and accused the United States of ‚Äúerroneous practices‚Äù by introducing a series of ‚Äúdiscriminatory restrictive measures.‚Äù These included restrictions on the sale of chip design software to China and barring American companies from using or financing artificial intelligence chips from the Chinese technology giant Huawei.

It also criticized the Trump administration‚Äôs announcement that it planned to ‚Äúaggressively revoke‚Äù the visas of Chinese students and that it would enhance scrutiny of all future applications from China, including Hong Kong.

The ministry wrote in its statement: ‚ÄúThe U.S. side has unilaterally escalated new economic and trade frictions, exacerbating the uncertainty and instability of bilateral economic and trade relations. Instead of reflecting on its own actions, it has turned the blame onto China.‚Äù

China said it would take measures to ‚Äúsafeguard its legitimate rights and interests‚Äù if the United States continued to harm Chinese interests.

The growing confrontation over the fragile trade truce between the world‚Äôs two largest economies has raised questions about whether they can strike a permanent accord within the 90-day deadline.

The United States has grown increasingly concerned about access to rare earth magnets, which are crucial for producing cars, semiconductors, aircraft and other vital items. China maintains a near monopoly on the production of rare earth metals.

American companies‚Äô ability to keep factories running could be in jeopardy without a sufficient supply of those magnets.

Jamieson Greer, the U.S. trade representative who negotiated the deal along with Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, said during a Friday appearance on CNBC that China was ‚Äúslow-rolling their compliance‚Äù and that the flow of some critical minerals has not returned to levels that American officials were expecting.

The agreement, announced on May 12, offered a temporary reprieve to the escalating trade tensions between the two largest economies. The United States had pushed tariffs on Chinese imports to 145 percent and China responded by raising import duties on American products to 125 percent.

Under the truce, the United States agreed to lower its tariffs to 30 percent, while China cut its import tax to 10 percent for 90 days.

title: Decenas de empresas iberoamericanas se re√∫nen en Espa√±a con la mirada puesta en Europa
content: Cerca de medio centenar de empresarios iberoamericanos se reunir√°n en la ciudad de Sevilla (sur de Espa√±a) del 2 al 4 de junio para abordar, entre otros asuntos, un acercamiento a Europa y a los merca ...
resumen:
Cerca de medio centenar de empresarios iberoamericanos se reunir√°n en la ciudad de Sevilla (sur de Espa√±a) del 2 al 4 de junio para abordar, entre otros asuntos, un acercamiento a Europa y a los mercados de Asia y Oriente Medio en un contexto internacional marcado por la incertidumbre.

El VIII Congreso del Consejo Empresarial Alianza por Iberoam√©rica (Ceapi) tendr√° lugar bajo el lema ‚ÄòConectamos continentes, construimos oportunidades‚Äô.

Este a√±o, la cita acoge a presidentes y miembros de las familias empresarias iberoamericanas con inversiones a ambos lados del Atl√°ntico, as√≠ como a l√≠deres institucionales y familias empresarias de toda la regi√≥n, que abordar√°n la apuesta por ‚ÄòM√°s Iberoam√©rica‚Äô y su papel un momento de acercamiento entre la UE y toda Latinoam√©rica.

El argentino Alejandro Bulgheroni, presidente de PanAmericanEnergy Group, el colombiano Carlos Julio Ardila, presidente del Grupo Ardila Lulle o el venezolano Juan Carlos Escotet, presidente de Abanca, son algunos de los invitados que se dar√°n cita en Sevilla.

En los paneles se debatir√°n los grandes desaf√≠os para fortalecer la inversi√≥n entre los 22 pa√≠ses iberoamericanos y las ponencias tratar√°n asuntos como la geoestrategia, energ√≠a, responsabilidad social, seguridad y defensa, innovaci√≥n y tecnolog√≠a, liderazgo, turismo, inversi√≥n, agroindustria, estrategia, empresa familiar, nueva era de Trump y cultura, entre otros.

resumen:
La guerra comercial desatada por Donald Trump ser√° el tema central de la reuni√≥n ministerial anual que celebra el martes y el mi√©rcoles la Organizaci√≥n para la Cooperaci√≥n y el Desarrollo Econ√≥mico (OCDE).

El secretario general, Mathias Cormann, y el economista jefe, Alvaro Pereira, presentar√°n el informe semestral de Perspectivas Econ√≥micas para 2025 y 2026.

La imposici√≥n de aranceles por parte de EE.UU. atenta contra la promoci√≥n del libre comercio.

Costa Rica, que ejerce este a√±o la presidencia de la ministerial, es uno de los pa√≠ses m√°s afectados por esa guerra comercial.

El ministro costarricense del Comercio Exterior, Manuel Tovar, deber√° encargarse de dar el tono a las discusiones, junto a Cormann.

Estados Unidos no ha enviado a Par√≠s una representaci√≥n de muy alto nivel. Al frente de su delegaci√≥n estar√° su representante para el Comercio, Jamieson Greer.

Por parte de Espa√±a, en la delegaci√≥n figura la secretaria de Estado de Comercio, Amparo L√≥pez Senovilla.

Este segundo mandato de Trump est√° suponiendo en la pr√°ctica el bloqueo de la iniciativa que se llevaba a cabo en el seno de la OCDE para alcanzar unos acuerdos sobre la fiscalidad internacional de las empresas.

El nuevo presidente estadounidense ha descalificado el acuerdo que hab√≠an alcanzado 140 pa√≠ses y jurisdicciones en 2020 para fijar un tipo m√≠nimo del 15 % para el impuesto de sociedades.

La OCDE afirm√≥ inmediatamente su voluntad de seguir adelante, pero no se conocen avances efectivos en la pr√°ctica y la cuesti√≥n no aparece en el programa de esta reuni√≥n ministerial.

Se mantiene el examen de la situaci√≥n de los pa√≠ses candidatos, que actualmente son ocho: tres latinoamericanos (Argentina, Brasil y Per√∫), tres europeos (Bulgaria, Croacia y Ruman√≠a) y dos asi√°ticos (Indonesia y Tailandia).

title: El vuelo intercontinental de Salvador Illa
content: Donald Trump, el se√±or de los aranceles , tiene secuestrada la atenci√≥n del planeta con una agenda pol√≠tica, econ√≥mica y comercial que avanza cada d√≠a, aunque sea a c√°mara lenta y entre tropiezos con ...

Las relaciones econ√≥micas e institucionales de Catalunya con los dos pa√≠ses son incipientes, pero se han producido avances, como el blindaje a una inversi√≥n de Lotte en Mont-Roig del Camp y el apoyo a los lazos asi√°ticos del Barcelona Super Computing Center. El objetivo era acompa√±ar proyectos en marcha, como una f√°brica de la catalana Werfen y la coreana Seegene en Lli√ß√† d‚ÄôAmunt. Se anuncia una segunda fase de la operaci√≥n, que se realizar√° en China el pr√≥ximo mes, donde existe el proyecto del desembarco de la empresa automovil√≠stica Chery, que ensamblar√° coches en la Zona Franca.

title: India Mulls Tariff Retaliation After US Rejects WTO Notice Over Steel and Aluminium Duties
content: India is considering retaliatory tariff measures after the United States formally rejected its WTO notice opposing steep duties on steel ...
resumen:
India is considering retaliatory tariff measures after the United States formally rejected its WTO notice opposing steep duties on steel and aluminium imports.

Washington claimed its tariff hikes were not ‚Äúsafeguard measures‚Äù and therefore not subject to WTO dispute resolution, officials familiar with the matter confirmed on Sunday.

India had issued a May 9 notification to the WTO stating its intent to suspend concessions and raise import duties on key US goods such as almonds and walnuts in response to the 25% duties Washington imposed in February, which took effect from March 12.

The Trump administration doubled the tariffs to 50% on May 30, citing national security concerns, effective June 4.

In a May 22 reply, the US told the WTO that the tariffs were not ‚Äúsafeguard measures‚Äù and India‚Äôs retaliation was ‚Äúnot consistent‚Äù with global trade rules.

The US has also refused to engage in dispute consultations, asserting the issue falls outside the Safeguards Agreement.

India‚Äôs Ministry of Commerce has not yet responded, but sources indicated New Delhi may go ahead with retaliatory tariffs if no progress is made in the ongoing Bilateral Trade Agreement (BTA) discussions.

A US delegation is expected to visit India this week to advance an early harvest trade deal.

According to Global Trade Research Initiative (GTRI), India exported $4.56 billion worth of iron, steel, and aluminium products to the US in FY25, including:
*   $587.5 million in iron and steel
*   $3.1 billion in articles of iron or steel
*   $860 million in aluminium products

GTRI founder and former trade officer Ajay Srivastava said, "These exports are now exposed to sharply higher US tariffs, threatening profitability."

India had earlier threatened retaliatory tariffs in 2018 over similar duties but withheld action amid trade negotiations.

title: El futuro del poder blando estadounidense
content: Si Trump cree que puede competir con China al mismo tiempo que debilita la confianza de los aliados de Estados Unidos, proclama aspiraciones imperiales, destruye la Usaid, silencia La Voz de Am√©rica, ...
resumen: El poder es la capacidad de conseguir que los dem√°s hagan lo que uno quiere. Esto se puede lograr con la coerci√≥n (‚Äúpalo‚Äù), el pago (‚Äúzanahoria‚Äù) y la atracci√≥n (‚Äúmiel‚Äù). Los dos primeros m√©todos son formas de poder duro, mientras que la atracci√≥n es poder blando. El poder blando surge de la cultura, los valores pol√≠ticos y la pol√≠tica exterior de los pa√≠ses. En lo inmediato, lo habitual es que el poder duro se imponga sobre el poder blando. Pero a largo plazo, suele ocurrir lo contrario. Quien tiene poder de atracci√≥n puede ahorrarse zanahorias y palos. Si los aliados lo ven como un actor ben√©volo y fiable, es m√°s probable que se dejen persuadir y sigan su ejemplo. Pero si lo ven como un mat√≥n indigno de confianza, lo m√°s probable es que no colaboren y procuren reducir la interdependencia tanto como puedan. Una idea adecuada del poder debe tener en cuenta no s√≥lo el aspecto duro, sino tambi√©n el aspecto blando. Aunque Maquiavelo dijo que para un pr√≠ncipe es preferible ser temido que amado, lo mejor es tener ambas cosas. Por lo general, el poder blando no es suficiente solo, y sus efectos tardan m√°s en concretarse; por eso a menudo existe para los l√≠deres pol√≠ticos la tentaci√≥n de recurrir al poder duro de la coerci√≥n o el pago. Pero cuando el poder duro se ejerce solo, puede implicar costos m√°s altos que cuando se lo combina con el poder blando de la atracci√≥n. Tras la Segunda Guerra Mundial, Estados Unidos era con diferencia el pa√≠s m√°s poderoso, e intent√≥ consagrar sus valores en el ‚Äúorden internacional liberal‚Äù, un marco que inclu√≠a a la Organizaci√≥n de las Naciones Unidas (ONU), las instituciones econ√≥micas de Bretton Woods y otros organismos multilaterales. Algunos presidentes estadounidenses no cumplieron ciertos aspectos del orden liberal, pero Donald Trump es el primero en rechazar la idea de que el poder blando tenga alg√∫n valor en pol√≠tica exterior. Sus primeras medidas al volver al cargo incluyeron sacar al pa√≠s del Acuerdo de Par√≠s y de la Organizaci√≥n Mundial de la Salud, a pesar de que las amenazas del cambio clim√°tico y de las pandemias son evidentes. Los efectos de que un gobierno estadounidense renuncie al poder blando son f√°ciles de predecir. Usar la coerci√≥n contra democracias aliadas (como Dinamarca o Canad√°) debilita la fe en nuestras alianzas. Amenazar a Panam√° reaviva el temor al imperialismo en toda Am√©rica Latina. Destruir la Agencia de los Estados Unidos para el Desarrollo Internacional (Usaid), creada por el presidente John F Kennedy en 1961, da√±a nuestra reputaci√≥n de benevolencia. Silenciar La Voz de Am√©rica es hacerles un regalo a las autocracias rivales. Imponer aranceles a pa√≠ses amigos nos hace parecer menos fiables. Tratar de limitar la libertad de expresi√≥n en casa nos resta credibilidad. Trump ha definido a China como el gran desaf√≠o de Estados Unidos; y China lleva invirtiendo en poder blando desde 2007, cuando su entonces presidente Hu Jintao dijo al Partido Comunista de China (PCCh) que era necesario aumentar el atractivo internacional del pa√≠s. Pero China enfrenta dos viejos grandes obst√°culos en este sentido. En primer lugar, sus disputas territoriales con varios vecinos. En segundo lugar, la insistencia del PCCh en mantener un control f√©rreo de la sociedad civil. Es probable que la democracia estadounidense sobreviva a cuatro a√±os de Trump. La cultura pol√≠tica de Estados Unidos es resiliente, y su constituci√≥n federal pone frenos al poder de los gobernantes. Hay una probabilidad razonable de que los dem√≥cratas recuperen el control de la C√°mara de Representantes en las elecciones de 2026. Adem√°s, la sociedad civil sigue siendo fuerte y la independencia de los tribunales se mantiene. El poder blando estadounidense padeci√≥ con las guerras de Vietnam e Irak y con el primer mandato de Trump, pero en ambos casos se recuper√≥. Sin embargo, cuando la confianza se pierde es dif√≠cil recuperarla. Rusia perdi√≥ la mayor parte de su poder blando tras la invasi√≥n de Ucrania, pero China est√° trabajando para llenar cualquier vac√≠o que deje Trump. Seg√∫n el presidente chino Xi Jinping, Oriente est√° en ascenso sobre Occidente. Si Trump cree que puede competir con China al mismo tiempo que debilita la confianza de los aliados de Estados Unidos, proclama aspiraciones imperiales, destruye la Usaid, silencia La Voz de Am√©rica, desaf√≠a las leyes de su pa√≠s y lo retira de los organismos de la ONU, es probable que fracase. Restaurar lo que ha destruido no ser√° imposible, pero s√≠ costoso. Joseph S Nye fue decano de la Escuela Kennedy de Harvard, subsecretario de Defensa de Estados Unidos y autor del libro de memorias A Life in the American Century (Polity Press, 2024).

En ese marco, afirm√≥ que en Estados Unidos ¬´quieren procesar al juez Alexandre de Moraes¬ª, miembro de la Corte Suprema, ¬´porque quiere parar a unos brasile√±os que est√°n en aquel pa√≠s haciendo cosas contra Brasil todos los d√≠as¬ª.
