title: Tariff shockwaves Indonesia‚Äôs export strategy under fire
content: Who is Priya Saroj MP? Rinku Singh's fianc√©e wanted to become a judge to protect Dalits before Akhilesh Yadav fielded her in Machhlishahr!
resumen:
US President Donald Trump implemented reciprocal import tariffs.

Tax Foundation summarized the reason for US‚Äô reciprocal tariffs on imported goods at the US Congress Joint Economic Committee Hearing on 18th Dec 2024: the relative decline in competitiveness of US industries compared to other nations, widening inequality, insufficient job creation and other domestic economic issues.

Researchers conclude that permanent import tariffs have only a modest impact on reducing trade deficits at best and suggest temporary tariffs can trigger a recession, an effect that deepens if trading partners retaliate.

President Trump‚Äôs 90-day postponement of reciprocal tariffs was followed by China after talks in Geneva.

MacroMicro‚Äôs Trade Policy Uncertainty Index in April rose to nearly ten times its level from last September.

The ten percent rate far exceeds the prior average tariff of two to three percent.

During Trump‚Äôs previous term, the US steadily increased its import tariffs on Chinese goods from around three per cent in January 2018 to almost twenty per cent by February 2020, while tariffs on the rest of the world rose only modestly from two to three per cent.

The US trade-balance deficit with both China and the rest of the world failed to shrink.

China sidestepped US tariffs by rerouting exports through third countries such as Mexico and ASEAN nations, and US domestic industries could not fully substitute for imports; import barriers disrupted production and stoked inflation.

Indonesian products supplanted Chinese goods in the US market and export-oriented Chinese Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) flowed into Indonesia.

Indonesia accelerated the signing of bilateral and regional trade agreements such as ASEAN Plus Three and Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) to diversify its export destinations and bolster supply-chain resilience.

The second salvo imposes extremely high rates on a vast array of trading partners simultaneously.

Exports from nearly every country to the US will contract.

China‚Äôs persistent overcapacity is likely to flood global markets, including Indonesia, with surplus goods.

US investors, deterred by harsher trading conditions abroad, will redirect capital back home, while rest-of-world investors chase lower-tariff jurisdictions.

China may shift more FDI toward Indonesia‚Äôs domestic market, but export-driven projects will wane.

Major industrial powers could resort to dumping surpluses at cut-rate prices, and if large economies retaliate in kind, global trade volumes may plunge further, dragging down growth worldwide.

The previous influx of export-oriented Chinese investment may slow while the domestic market is still uncertain.

Indonesia can strengthen its trade defence and remedies in anticipation of the surge of dumping and illegal imports.

Exports to the US account for less than ten percent of Indonesia‚Äôs total shipments.

Indonesia can proactively pursue bilateral negotiations with the United States, mirroring moves by other ASEAN members while refraining from retaliation.

Indonesia may consider initiating Preferential Trade Agreements or bilateral limited Free Trade Agreements with the US.

Indonesia can also leverage its status under the US Generalized System of Preferences to seek a limited Preferential/ Free Trade Agreement.

Indonesia‚Äôs average Most Favoured Nation tariffs in 2023 were moderate and applied uniformly at around eight percent.

The US enjoyed a services-trade surplus of USD 1.6 billion in 2023 despite a goods-trade deficit.

The Indonesian government must reassess its own non-tariff measures, since US sanctions have cited both Indonesia‚Äôs import duties and regulatory barriers.

Indonesia can step in to supply goods that complement exports from heavily tariffed nations, capturing new opportunities in global supply chains.

Indonesia can deepen production partnerships over the long term by attracting FDI into intermediate-goods manufacturing with countries facing lower US tariffs such as Japan and expand its diplomatic outreach by accelerating cooperation frameworks including BRICS and OECD accession among others.

Sweeping reforms to enhance the business climate, raising productivity and lowering high-cost economic structures are essential, as is an active role in World Trade Organisation reform to revitalise multilateral trade.

Upgrading logistics and industrial infrastructure can target broad competitiveness rather than aligning with any single foreign investor‚Äôs supply chain and ensure that any re-export of foreign-origin goods satisfies Rules of Origin requirements with substantial value additions compared to mere goods in transit.

Stronger enforcement against illegal imports and more robust anti-dumping measures will protect domestic industries from unfair competition.

By maintaining an independent foreign policy, Indonesia can preserve diplomatic flexibility and preparing for non-economic conditions such as domestic politics, foreign policy and defence commitments will round out its readiness.

title: China rechaza haber violado acuerdo sobre aranceles, como denuncia EU; advierte que ‚Äútomar√° medidas firmes‚Äù

title: China acusa a Estados Unidos de ‚Äòsocavar gravemente‚Äô la tregua arancelaria de mayo en Ginebra
content: China rechaz√≥ este lunes las acusaciones de Estados Unidos sobre un supuesto incumplimiento del acuerdo alcanzado en mayo para reducir temporalmente los aranceles bilaterales, y acus√≥ a Washington de ...
resumen:
China rechaz√≥ las acusaciones de Estados Unidos sobre un supuesto incumplimiento del acuerdo alcanzado en mayo para reducir temporalmente los aranceles bilaterales, y acus√≥ a Washington de ‚Äúsocavar gravemente‚Äù el consenso logrado en las negociaciones comerciales celebradas en Ginebra.

Pek√≠n asegur√≥ que ha actuado ‚Äúcon responsabilidad‚Äù y que ‚Äúha cumplido estrictamente‚Äù lo pactado con Estados Unidos, en virtud del cual suspendi√≥ o cancel√≥ algunas de las medidas arancelarias y no arancelarias adoptadas anteriormente en respuesta a los grav√°menes estadounidenses.

El portavoz ministerial indic√≥ que China ha sido firme en la defensa de sus derechos leg√≠timos y sincera en la aplicaci√≥n del consenso, y acus√≥ a Washington de ‚Äúintroducir sucesivas restricciones discriminatorias‚Äù, entre ellas nuevas gu√≠as de control a la exportaci√≥n de chips de inteligencia artificial, la suspensi√≥n de ventas de software de dise√±o de semiconductores y la revocaci√≥n de visados para estudiantes chinos.

Estas acciones violan tanto el acuerdo alcanzado en Ginebra como los compromisos adquiridos por los presidentes de ambos pa√≠ses durante una llamada telef√≥nica mantenida el pasado 17 de enero.

Pek√≠n sostuvo que Estados Unidos ‚Äúha distorsionado los hechos con acusaciones infundadas‚Äù y advirti√≥ que, si Washington persiste en da√±ar sus intereses, China ‚Äútomar√° medidas firmes‚Äù para defenderse.

La cartera comercial subray√≥ que el comunicado conjunto de Ginebra fue fruto de un consenso arduamente alcanzado sobre la base del respeto mutuo y la igualdad e inst√≥ a Estados Unidos a corregir de inmediato sus acciones err√≥neas y a trabajar junto con China para preservar la estabilidad de las relaciones econ√≥micas y comerciales.

Las declaraciones del Ministerio de Comercio se producen en respuesta a las recientes afirmaciones del presidente estadounidense, Donald Trump, quien acus√≥ a China de ‚Äúviolar totalmente‚Äù el acuerdo alcanzado a mediados de mayo para rebajar temporalmente los altos aranceles bilaterales.

Ambas potencias hab√≠an pactado una tregua arancelaria de tres meses, reduciendo Estados Unidos sus tarifas del 145% al 30%, y China del 125% al 10%.

En los √∫ltimos d√≠as se han recrudecido las tensiones, con nuevas restricciones impuestas por Washington y una ca√≠da del 20% en las importaciones estadounidenses de bienes en abril.

El secretario del Tesoro, Scott Bessent, reconoci√≥ la semana pasada que las negociaciones est√°n ‚Äúestancadas‚Äù y apunt√≥ que una llamada entre Trump y su hom√≥logo chino, Xi Jinping, podr√≠a desbloquear la situaci√≥n.

El asesor econ√≥mico de la Casa Blanca, Kevin Hassett, asegur√≥ este domingo que a√∫n no hay una conversaci√≥n programada entre ambos l√≠deres, aunque espera que los dos mandatarios puedan hablar sobre comercio esta semana entrante.

title: Las fechas clave de la guerra arancelaria de Trump que ha dinamitado el comercio mundial
content: Desde que asumi√≥ el cargo de presidente de EE.UU. en el mes de enero, Donald Trump se ha dedicado a repartir tasas a las importaciones de casi todos los pa√≠ses. Este es un repaso de las principales de ...
resumen:
Desde que asumi√≥ el cargo de presidente de EE.UU. en enero, Donald Trump se ha dedicado a repartir tasas a las importaciones de casi todos los pa√≠ses.

El 1 de febrero, Trump anunci√≥ aranceles del 25% a todas las importaciones procedentes de M√©xico y Canad√° y un 10% a las importaciones de China.

El 3 de febrero, la Administraci√≥n de Trump paus√≥ los aranceles a M√©xico y Canad√° durante 30 d√≠as.

El 7 de febrero se anunci√≥ el retraso de la imposici√≥n de aranceles a China.

El 10 de febrero, Trump anunci√≥ un arancel del 25% sobre el acero y el aluminio.

El 3 de marzo se reanudaron los aranceles del 25% a M√©xico y Canad√°, mientras que a China se duplicaron -pasaron a ser de un 20%-.

El 6 de marzo Trump paus√≥ temporalmente los aranceles a productos de M√©xico y Canad√° que estuvieran cubiertos por acuerdos comerciales.

Impuso aranceles del 25% a la importaci√≥n de coches.

El 2 de abril, Trump impuso aranceles a todo el mundo con una base del 10% para todas las importaciones.

Espa√±a y la Uni√≥n Europea recibieron un 20% de tasas, China un 34%, Taiw√°n un 32% o Corea del Sur un 25%.

Los √∫nicos pa√≠ses que se libraron de estas tasas fueron Rusia, Cuba y Bielorrusia.

Trump paus√≥ los aranceles rec√≠procos durante 90 d√≠as, excepto para China, pa√≠s al que se los aument√≥ hasta el 145%.

China reaccion√≥ con unas tarifas del 125% a EE.UU.

El mes de mayo comenz√≥ con el anuncio de un arancel del 100% a todas las pel√≠culas producidas fuera de Estados Unidos.

Trump y el primer ministro brit√°nico, Keir Starmer acordaron que los aranceles sobre exportaciones brit√°nicas se mantendr√°n en un 10%.

China y Estados Unidos acordaron reducir durante 90 d√≠as los aranceles rec√≠procos.

Trump anunci√≥ aranceles del 50% a la Uni√≥n Europea, aunque d√≠as despu√©s se retract√≥ de su decisi√≥n y los paus√≥ hasta el 9 de julio.

El 28 de mayo un tribunal de comercio bloque√≥ su aplicaci√≥n.

Un tribunal federal de operaciones los restableci√≥ temporalmente.

title: Asian stocks fall as Trump fires fresh volley in trade war
content: Uncertainty looms over new threats to steel and aluminium tariffs, as China is accused of violating the trade consensus.
resumen: Asian stocks fell Monday. Donald Trump doubled tariffs on steel and aluminium and accused China of violating last month‚Äôs agreement to slash tit-for-tat levies. Trump said Friday he would jack up steel and aluminium to 50%, from 25%. He also claimed Beijing had ‚Äútotally violated‚Äù last month‚Äôs agreement with China to cut eye-watering tariffs for 90 days. Commerce secretary Howard Lutnick said Beijing had been ‚Äúslow-rolling the deal‚Äù. Chinese officials accused Washington of making ‚Äúbogus charges and unreasonably accused China of violating the consensus‚Äù. The developments have thrown the trade war back into the spotlight. Kai Wang, Asia equity market strategist at Morningstar, said, ‚ÄúAs we await whether the 90-day truce will result in a more permanent resolution, we are left wondering what may happen if progress stalls and the US and China are unable to make a deal‚Äù. Hong Kong dropped more than two percent. Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei, Manila and Jakarta also fell, with Shanghai closed for a holiday. Oil prices surged after Opec and other key producers hiked output for July. The dollar also retreated on concerns about the US economy as Trump continues to push a bill to extend tax cuts and slash welfare spending. Moody‚Äôs lowered the US top-ranking credit rating. JPMorgan Chase chief executive Jamie Dimon voiced concern Sunday at the risk of a looming US debt market crisis sparked by Trump‚Äôs policies.

title: Las elecciones no tradicionales de 2028
content: No muchos l√≠deres o dirigentes pol√≠ticos pueden entender que las elecciones del 2028 se perfilan como las m√°s trascendentes en tres d√©cadas porque en esos comicios estar√° en juego -sin exagerar- la su ...
resumen:
Las elecciones del 2028 se perfilan como las m√°s trascendentes en tres d√©cadas porque en esos comicios estar√° en juego la supervivencia del espacio democr√°tico y de la estabilidad macroecon√≥mica, que sobreviven y se consolidan desde 1994.

M√°s de una veintena de aspirantes presidenciales han salido a destiempo de la gatera electoral con discursos y propuestas extra√≠dos del refrigerador de la historia, sin darse cuenta que desde antes de la pandemia de 2020, en la cocina del mundo se cuecen otros intereses que provocan t√≥xica humareda.

El liderazgo pol√≠tico actu√≥ con diligencia y valent√≠a al enfrentar los efectos de la crisis bancaria de 2002-2004, la inmobiliaria en Estados Unidos, de 2008, la derivada de la sentencia 68-13, y la mega crisis pand√©mica del 2020, sin olvidar la de 1994, que evit√≥ una guerra civil.

En los √∫ltimos ocho a√±os el mundo ha cambiado radicalmente con el progresivo derrumbe de gobiernos socialdem√≥cratas en Europa y America, reemplazados por reg√≠menes o corrientes ideol√≥gicas parlamentarias de extrema derecha con tinte de ultra nacionalismo, xenofobia, antiinmigrantes y neoliberales.

En el √°mbito econ√≥mico, a nivel global se acent√∫a la incertidumbre con la prolongaci√≥n de la guerra entre Rusia y Occidente, en el territorio de Ucrania, y la masacre de Israel contra la poblaci√≥n civil de Gaza, sin que se haya reparado el derrumbe en la cadena del comercio mundial provocado por la pandemia.

El retorn√≥ de Donald Trump a la Casa Blanca ha puesto al mundo patas arriba, con la declaratoria de una guerra de aranceles, que no solo agrava la inseguridad econ√≥mica, sino tambi√©n la reconfiguraci√≥n del mapa mundial en t√©rminos de bloques econ√≥micos y pol√≠ticos.

Rep√∫blica dominicana apenas representa un peque√±o trazo en esa cartograf√≠a de intereses pol√≠ticos y econ√≥micos, por lo que se expone a que literalmente sea borrada de estructuras de importancia geopol√≠tica, lo que implica, incluso, riesgo de que cualquier boceto imperial borre en la isla l√≠neas fronterizas o pol√≠ticas.

Las elecciones de 2028 no ser√°n ni podr√≠an ser tradicionales circos electorales donde don dinero construye escaleras o elevadores para que s√∫bditos de sus intereses asciendan a las poltronas del Poder, porque lo que estar√° en juego es la propia supervivencia del gentilicio nacional.

Los 43 mil millones de d√≥lares que ingresan a la econom√≠a impulsan crecimiento, pero no desarrollo, m√°s a√∫n cuando por temor los gobiernos no se atreven a dise√±ar y aplicar un modelo de reforma fiscal que garantice redistribuci√≥n del ingreso. He ah√≠ el otro problema que se reflejar√° en 2028.

title: The latest on Trump‚Äôs tariffs and his massive domestic policy bill
content: More uncertainty surrounds President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs as a new week begins. Meanwhile, the White House is ramping up its halting efforts to secure ceasefires in Gaza and Ukraine. Follow for live ...
resumen:
**June 1, 2025: Donald Trump presidency news**

*   **Trade war:** President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs ‚Äúare not going away,‚Äù his commerce secretary said Sunday, despite a legal battle over the president‚Äôs use of emergency powers to implement them. Trade tensions appear to be ramping back up with China.
*   **‚ÄúBig, beautiful bill‚Äù:** Senate Republicans will work this week on their version of the massive spending and tax cuts package advancing Trump‚Äôs domestic policy agenda. GOP leaders are trying to win over conservative critics concerned the bill will increase the federal deficit.
*   **Foreign policy frustrations:** Trump‚Äôs Middle East envoy slammed Hamas‚Äô response to a US-backed Gaza ceasefire proposal Saturday, and skepticism surrounds the Russia-Ukraine peace talks planned in Istanbul on Monday. The president has faced diplomatic roadblocks as he tries to fulfill a campaign pledge to end the conflicts.
*   Trump pulled his NASA pick after top aide lobbied against the nominee, source says. Trump withdrew Isaacman‚Äôs nomination days after Musk, the SpaceX CEO who served as a senior adviser to the president, departed Washington with a plan to refocus on his companies. Trump selected Isaacman in December. Trump said on social media Saturday night that he pulled Isaacman‚Äôs nomination after a ‚Äúthorough review of prior associations.‚Äù The White House said earlier Saturday that ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs essential that the next leader of NASA is in complete alignment with President Trump‚Äôs America First agenda.‚Äù Records on OpenSecrets show Isaacman donated to Democrats as recently as the 2024 election cycle, though he donated to Republicans in prior years.
*   Rubio spoke with his Russian counterpart by phone today, State Department says. Secretary of State Marco Rubio spoke with Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov today, the US State Department said, ahead of a key meeting between Russian and Ukrainian delegations in Turkey. The call came ‚Äúat Russia‚Äôs request.‚Äù
*   White House wasn't given a heads-up about major Ukrainian strikes on Russian bases, official says. The Trump administration was not briefed ahead of time about a significant and ambitious Ukrainian operation targeting Russian air bases this weekend, an administration official told CNN. Ukraine estimates that its operation against Russian air bases caused $7 billion in damages.
*   "Absolute disaster": Senate Democrats preview criticisms of Trump megabill. Senate Democrats previewed their arguments against the massive domestic policy bill that the upper chamber will now have to address. Sen. Chris Murphy of Connecticut called the bill an ‚Äúabsolute disaster‚Äù for middle class and poor Americans.
*   "We‚Äôve got to keep the pressure on Hamas,". GOP senator says after return from Israel. The US needs to ‚Äúkeep the pressure on Hamas‚Äù to get remaining hostages out of Gaza, Republican Sen. Dave McCormick said today after returning from his trip to Israel, where he met with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. McCormick criticized Hamas for not agreeing to a US-backed ceasefire proposal. Hamas released a statement today saying it is ready to ‚Äúimmediately‚Äù begin indirect negotiations on resolving the remaining ‚Äúpoints of contention‚Äù with the US-backed proposal. Cindy McCain, the executive director of the United Nations World Food Programme, warned today there will be a ‚Äúhumanitarian catastrophe‚Äù in Gaza ‚Äúlike none other‚Äù without an immediate ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.
*   Tariffs "are not going away," Trump's commerce secretary says. Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick emphasized today that President Donald Trump‚Äôs 90-day pause for tariff negotiations is a hard deadline ‚Äî and vowed that despite a federal court ruling earlier this week, tariffs ‚Äúare not going away.‚Äù The secretary predicted a ‚Äúlot of deals‚Äù will be done ahead of the July deadline. Lutnick also weighed in on last week‚Äôs court ruling blocking tariffs that Trump imposed using emergency powers. The administration appealed the decision, and an appeals court ruled that the tariffs can remain in effect while the case is being heard. Trump claimed on Truth Social today that a ruling against him would mean ‚ÄúEconomic ruination‚Äù for the country and allow other nations to take advantage of the US.
*   Musk defends DOGE as he distances himself from Trump‚Äôs agenda. Tech billionaire Elon Musk defended the Department of Government Efficiency in an interview aired today on CBS, arguing that his initiative became a scapegoat. Though he remained cordial and supportive during his farewell Oval Office appearance with President Donald Trump on Friday, Musk has more recently sharpened his criticism of the president.
*   Vought downplays role of Project 2025 in Trump policy agenda. Office of Management and Budget Director Russ Vought distanced himself from suggestions that he is implementing elements of Project 2025, a sweeping conservative policy blueprint he helped craft, into the Trump administration‚Äôs agenda.
*   GOP backers are pushing back on critics saying Trump‚Äôs bill will add to the deficit. Speaker Mike Johnson repeatedly denied today that the ‚Äúbig, beautiful bill‚Äù passed by the House last month will increase the national debt. The nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office has predicted the bill could add around $3.8 trillion to the deficit over eight years. The Joint Committee on Taxation has since increased that estimate to $3.94 trillion.
*   Trump‚Äôs 50% tariffs on steel are a national security measure, top economic adviser says. White House National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett defended President Donald Trump‚Äôs recent doubling of steel tariffs to 50%, framing the measure as a critical step to ensuring the United States is prepared in the event of war. Trump announced at a Pennsylvania steel plant Friday that he would set tariffs on steel imported into the US at 50% starting June 4.
*   House minority leader accuses Trump administration of trying to intimidate Democrats. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries accused the Trump administration of trying to intimidate Democrats as confrontations with federal officials have escalated in recent weeks.
*   Bessent says Trump and Xi will speak "very soon" as trade tensions escalate. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent said President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping plan to speak ‚Äúvery soon,‚Äù but declined to set a date for the long-awaited, high-stakes conversation between the leaders as Trump and other top US officials appear to escalate tensions with Beijing.
*   OMB director pushes back on Musk's concern that Trump policy bill will increase deficit. Russ Vought, the director of the Office of Management and Budget, directly challenged criticism from Elon Musk and several Republican senators that President Donald Trump‚Äôs ‚Äúbig, beautiful‚Äù bill increases the federal deficit.
*   Trump calls on the Senate to pass his domestic policy bill and clarifies a key promise. President Donald Trump is urging the Senate to retain provisions from conservative hardliners in his expansive domestic policy bill. Trump returned to social media to spotlight a key tax cut promise from his campaign that was left out of the sweeping policy bill: no taxes on Social Security.
*   Trump ramped up his trade war again last week. President Donald Trump made the latest move in his ever-evolving trade war Friday, announcing at a Pennsylvania steel plant that he plans to double tariffs on the alloy. Trump told a crowd at the US Steel facility outside Pittsburgh that he plans to jack up tariffs on the material to 50%. Trump on March 12 imposed sweeping 25

title: Can Pakistan leverage US food imports?
content: TRADE POLICIES Trump's tariff plan has sent shockwaves around the world. The WTO warns of a 0.2 per cent shrinkage of global trade, as opposed to a growth forecast of 2.7 per cent before the new ...
resumen:
Trump's tariff plan has sent shockwaves around the world. The WTO warns of a 0.2 per cent shrinkage of global trade, as opposed to a growth forecast of 2.7 per cent before the new tariff policy.

Pakistan is moving towards trade liberalisation. Pakistan has opted to propose a zero-tariff bilateral trade agreement with Washington and introduced a National Trade Policy 2025-30, which aims to liberalise trade by lowering the maximum customs duty (CD) to 15 per cent and eliminating additional customs duties (ACD) and regulatory duties (RD).

The US is a major export destination for Pakistani goods and Pakistan lacks the economic prowess to sustain a $564 million export loss.

Negotiatory policy responses are critical to mitigating the 29 per cent tariff imposed by the U.S. in retaliation for Pakistan‚Äôs $3 billion trade surplus, which would cost Pakistan only approximately $85 million in tariff revenue.

Pakistan is a severely food insecure country with 20.7 per cent of the population suffering from malnutrition, 40 per cent of children under 5 suffering from stunting, and the economy losing 3.0 per cent of GDP to malnutrition.

Pakistan is the 28th largest export market for US foods and agricultural-related products. The top food imports from the US consist of tree nuts, pulses and processed foods. Pakistan imposes high tariffs and additional regulatory duties on these products, except for pulses.

Imported items are not included in an average Pakistani's diet.

Lowered prices and increased quantity due to trade liberalisation policies would not add any value to Pakistan‚Äôs food landscape, and a lower price would only impact the already affluent people, for whom the cost of a healthy diet is already affordable.

Trade liberalisation would entail easy and affordable access of processed foods into Pakistani market and can threaten the acceleration of ‚Äònutrition transition‚Äô.

Pakistan should opt for a multidimensional approach by exploring various strategies to strengthen the country‚Äôs economic position in the global arena and combat food insecurity.

Pakistan Pure Food Laws (PFL) regulates processed foods but these regulations mostly deal with additives and food preservatives. The Government should also work towards limiting the excessive use of problematic nutrients like trans fats, sodium and sugar in processed foods.

Labelling is an effective tool, as it provides consumers with the instant knowledge needed to make informed purchases. Labelling should be harmonised to ensure smooth and healthy trade.

Pulses are a staple in the Pakistani diet across all socio-economic backgrounds. Pakistan's pulse consumption far exceeds its domestic production. The import of pulses has already increased 12.95 per cent compared to the previous fiscal year.

A zero-tariff agreement on the table would make Pakistan's pulse market more inviting to US exporters.

Pakistan would become vulnerable to external shocks such as geopolitical tensions (Ukraine-Russia war, Pakistan-India tensions, etc), climate change-induced supply disruptions, or shifts in US trade policy.

Food imports also risk pushing local businesses out and taking over the market.

Trade liberalisation threatens the dumping of GMO crops in Pakistan.

NTBs can be used to restrict the dumping of GMO crops in Pakistan. Pakistan has an extensive set of SOPs in place for importing GMOs. Pakistan needs to implement biosafety NTBs, like mandatory labelling if GMO content is greater than 0.9 per cent. The government should work towards introducing quotas on the import of GMO soya bean.

Pakistan should opt for a multidimensional approach by exploring various strategies -- including tariff negotiation, trade diversification, the promotion of value-added products and investment in local processing industries -- to strengthen Pakistan‚Äôs economic position in the global arena and combat food insecurity.

title: (EDITORIAL from Korea Times on June 2)
content: Erratic tariff strategy Policy inconsistency fuels trade instability: Korea must remain strategic. The trade landscape between the United States and its partners has once again be ...
resumen: The trade landscape between the United States and its partners has been thrown into confusion. A recent ruling by the U.S. Court of International Trade invalidated President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariffs, finding they exceeded the authority granted to the executive branch under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA). The U.S. Court of Appeals temporarily reinstated the tariffs, granting the Trump administration continued leeway until the appeals process concludes. The administration would pursue the matter all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court. This legal tug-of-war reveals deeper systemic issues in Trump's trade policy: unpredictability, legal overreach and the weaponization of tariffs for political gain. These features have destabilized global supply chains and eroded America's credibility as a reliable economic partner. For countries like Korea, this inconsistency poses significant strategic and economic challenges. Trump's approach to trade has been characterized by an "America First" mantra that treats economic relationships as zero-sum games. The use of tariffs as bargaining chips has made it nearly impossible for allies and adversaries alike to plan and respond with confidence. The Trump administration repeatedly threatened steep tariffs on key exports such as cars and steel, only to later renegotiate under duress or delay enforcement for strategic timing. Trump's reliance on dubious legal justifications further compounds the issue. IEEPA, intended for genuine national emergencies, was stretched beyond reasonable limits to support trade objectives. The initial court ruling noted that trade deficits do not constitute national emergencies and that the executive branch cannot bypass congressional authority over commerce. The Trump administration's attempt to circumvent these checks through legal gymnastics not only undermines domestic institutional integrity but also alienates close allies. Trump's allies have signaled they are prepared to continue pressing forward through legal loopholes. White House National Economic Council director Kevin Hassett publicly stated there are "three or four other methods" to impose tariffs if courts block the current path. For Korea, such erratic policymaking creates an environment of constant uncertainty. Korea must avoid being reactive. Korea should focus on reinforcing its strategic position through three core actions: strengthen the competitiveness of its key export industries, accelerate export market diversification, and deepen multilateral and regional partnerships and assert its interests through global trade institutions such as the World Trade Organization. Trump must rethink his approach. Lasting influence comes not from coercion but from consistency, respect for international rules and adherence to domestic legal boundaries. He should pursue long-term competitiveness through investment in innovation, workforce development and infrastructure. The U.S. president must acknowledge that alienating economic partners through threats and unilateralism weakens, not strengthens, American leadership. If Trump's trade policy is to be taken seriously on the global stage, it must evolve from a tool of bluster to an engine of stable, mutual prosperity. The international community must brace for renewed volatility. Korea, by investing in its capabilities and anchoring its diplomacy in strategy rather than reaction, can chart a course through this turbulence with resilience and clarity.

title: A North American customs union may help ease trade issues
content: In an attempt to escape the U.S.-China trade war, many Chinese companies and affiliates have moved production or set up satellite production in Mexico in cities such as Juarez and Tijuana. This is ...
resumen:
The U.S.-China trade war resulted in a lowering of U.S. tariffs of 145 percent on Chinese imports to 30 percent, and a lowering of 125 percent tariffs on U.S. imports into China to 10 percent. A truce was declared for 90 days as negotiations take place.

Chinese companies have moved production or set up satellite production in Mexico to avoid U.S. import tariffs and benefit from reduced or zero tariffs under the U.S-Mexico-Canada-Agreement (USMCA).

The Trump Administration has threatened tariffs on Chinese companies producing in Mexico and shipping their products to the U.S.

A possible solution could involve a modified version of a customs union, where USMCA members Mexico, Canada, and the U.S. lower tariffs among themselves and develop a unified common external tariff on imports from non-member countries.

A twist on a North American customs union could be a common policy among members on foreign investment, in this case from China, in either of the three USMCA countries.

Mexico, Canada, and the U.S. could also develop a policy applying special tariffs on Chinese companies in North America.

The USMCA is up for review in 2026.

The formation of a customs union would take trust and goodwill among the three North American partners.

Jerry Pacheco is President of the Border Industrial Association.

title: EU threatens countermeasures over Trump's steel tariffs hike
content: The European Commission said on Saturday that Europe was prepared to retaliate against President Donald Trump‚Äôs plan to double tariffs on imported steel and aluminum, raising the prospect of an ...
resumen: The European Commission said on Saturday that Europe was prepared to retaliate against President Donald Trump‚Äôs plan to double tariffs on imported steel and aluminum. Trump announced on Friday that he would increase tariffs on imported steel and aluminum to 50 percent from 25 percent. The European Commission said it "strongly" regrets Trump's plan to increase tariffs and that the EU is prepared to impose countermeasures. The EU had paused its countermeasures to create space for continued negotiations. If no mutually acceptable solution is reached, both existing and additional EU measures will automatically take effect on 14 July ‚Äî or earlier, if circumstances require. Trump said the increased tariff would also apply to aluminum products and that it would take effect on Wednesday. The US is the world's largest steel importer, excluding the EU, with a total of 26.2 million tonnes of imported steel in 2024, according to the Department of Commerce.

title: Which two American companies could come out ahead with tariffs?

President Trump's tariff policies have brought uncertainty to the stock market. The S&P 500, Nasdaq Composite, and Dow Jones Industrial Average experienced double-digit declines after the April 2 announcement, but rebounded. Tariffs are a tax on imported or exported goods, used to negotiate trade deals and encourage domestic manufacturing. Economists worry about the cost of increased manufacturing investment in the U.S., potentially leading to inflation.

Two companies that could emerge as winners are:

1.  **Home Depot (NYSE: HD)**: The home improvement industry in the U.S. is essentially a duopoly between Home Depot and Lowe's. Home Depot sources more than half of its inventory from domestic vendors.
2.  **Nucor**: Higher prices for imported steel from other countries, particularly China, should benefit Nucor. Companies across different sectors have committed to increased domestic manufacturing, including Project Stargate, a $500 billion vision for more artificial intelligence infrastructure in the U.S.

*   **T√≠tulo I: Eficiencia Organizativa.** Introduce medidas para simplificar la estructura administrativa, reducir cargas burocr√°ticas y mejorar la coordinaci√≥n entre las diferentes administraciones.
*   **T√≠tulo II: Eficiencia en la Gesti√≥n de los Recursos Humanos.** Se enfoca en la optimizaci√≥n de la plantilla, la formaci√≥n de los empleados p√∫blicos y la promoci√≥n de la igualdad y la conciliaci√≥n.
*   **T√≠tulo III: Eficiencia en la Gesti√≥n Econ√≥mico-Financiera.** Contempla medidas para mejorar la planificaci√≥n presupuestaria, la gesti√≥n de los contratos p√∫blicos y el control del gasto.

El proyecto de ley incluye la creaci√≥n de la Oficina Nacional de Evaluaci√≥n, que se encargar√° de evaluar el impacto de las pol√≠ticas p√∫blicas y proponer mejoras. Tambi√©n se prev√© la creaci√≥n de un registro de altos cargos y directivos del sector p√∫blico, con el objetivo de aumentar la transparencia y la rendici√≥n de cuentas.

title: The most important economic reform
content: What‚Äôs the most important economic reform that President Ferdinand ‚ÄúBongbong‚Äù Marcos, Jr. can do at this stage? Is it to amend the restrictive economic provisions in the Constitution? Is it to ...
resumen:
The most important economic reform that President Ferdinand ‚ÄúBongbong‚Äù Marcos, Jr. can do is to reverse the strong peso and undervalue the currency. Weakening the peso will stimulate exports, protect local industries, increase incomes of Overseas Filipino Worker (OFW) families, and make the Philippines more attractive to foreign investments.

The balance of trade worsened, with imports exceeding exports and ballooning to $52 billion in 2024. A weak peso will benefit agriculture, stimulate agricultural exports, and protect farmers. The government should abolish quantitative restrictions and use the weak peso to protect local farmers. A weak peso will also be good for the tourism and mining industries and act as an economic stimulus for OFW families. It will also shield the Philippines from cheap Chinese goods.

The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas‚Äô (BSP) studies show that the pass-through rate of a depreciated currency to inflation is small. A weak peso is the strongest incentive for foreign investors. A strong peso will undercut tariff advantages and negate benefits under Free Trade Agreements.

To reverse the strong peso, the BSP can cut interest rates and buy dollars to weaken the peso and build up its reserves. The BSP can always sterilize the increased pesos by floating its bonds.

The BSP‚Äôs studies show that the pass-through rate, or the rise in inflation due to depreciation, is insignificant. The incomes of domestic players ‚Äî OFWs, exporters, local industries, and BPOs, will rise and compensate for any one-time blip in oil prices. If the BSP won‚Äôt listen, Congress should pass a law amending the BSP Charter to make balancing price stability with growth and full employment as BSP‚Äôs primary objective. The Philippines should even consider scrapping the regime of free capital movement and adopting a semi-fixed exchange rate and soft capital controls.

China devalued the yuan by 21% in 1989, 17% from 1990 to 1993, and 33% in 1994. Vietnam depreciated its currency by 43.6% between 2002 and 2016. Vietnam experienced export growth of more than 10% per annum compared to the Philippines‚Äô paltry export growth of 3% per annum during the same period. Vietnam doubled its export-to-GDP ratio from 40% in 1999 to 87% in 2023 and became the sixth biggest trading partner of the US. The Philippines posted an export-to-GDP ratio of 28% in 2023. Vietnam‚Äôs FDI reached $38 billion in 2024 compared to the Philippines‚Äô FDI at $8.9 billion in 2024.

In 1946, the US forced the Philippines to adopt a P2 to $1 exchange rate. In 1949, the Philippines experienced a foreign exchange crisis. Japan‚Äôs exchange rate was ¬•3.50 to $1 before the war, ¬•50 to $1 in 1946 and ¬•360 in 1949. Japan‚Äôs lost decades can be traced directly to the Plaza Accord.

A weak peso is a net plus for government revenues. Weakening or undervaluing the peso is the most important, most effective, fastest, and easiest to implement economic reform.

Calixto V. Chikiamco is a member of the board of IDEA (Institute for Development and Econometric Analysis).

title: Dem Claim That Trump Tariffs Would Cause Prices To ‚ÄòSoar‚Äô Crumbles Due To Positive Economic News
content: A recent Democratic ad campaign claiming President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs have caused prices to ‚Äúsoar‚Äù is undercut by recent data ...
resumen: A Democratic ad campaign claimed President Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs have caused prices to ‚Äúsoar‚Äù. House Majority Forward (HMF), the nonprofit arm of a House Democratic leadership-aligned super PAC, announced a series of ads Wednesday targeting 26 House Republicans for supporting the president‚Äôs tariffs, which HMF claims has caused prices to skyrocket. Several markers of inflation fell to four-year-lows in April while Americans‚Äô wages are rising faster than the rate of inflation. The personal consumption expenditures (PCE) price index slowed to 2.1% in April, an increase of just 0.1% for the month, the lowest rate since February 2021. The consumer price index slowed to just 2.3% year-over-year and 0.2% month-over-month in April, the slowest rate in more than four years. Personal incomes also rose 0.8% for the month, nearly tripling expectations, according to the Commerce Department. In April grocery prices saw their biggest drop in five years since September 2020, largely driven by a sharp decline in the price of eggs, which fell to their lowest price in roughly 40 years. U.S. consumer confidence also surged in May, reversing five straight months of decline, according to a report from the The Conference Board. EJ Antoni, chief economist at the Heritage Foundation, stated that the claim that prices are soaring is empirically false by any measure. NRCC Spokesman Mike Marinella stated that prices continue to fall, and the economy is booming under President Trump and Republicans in Congress. Antoni cautioned that persistent high tariffs coupled with a trade war with China could ‚Äúsignificantly raise prices‚Äù but that scenario has not yet happened. House Democrats claimed that Congressional Republicans‚Äô reforms to Medicaid in the president‚Äôs sweeping tax and spending bill would kick 13.7 million Americans off of the entitlement program‚Äôs rolls. The New York Times fact-checked the claim as ‚Äúan exaggeration.‚Äù Democrats added in roughly four million additional people who are expected to lose Medicaid coverage due to the expiration of a policy unrelated to the ‚Äúbig, beautiful bill.‚Äù The House-drafted proposal would kick off 1.4 million illegal migrants who receive coverage through state Medicaid programs. Nearly 5 million Americans are also slated to lose coverage rather than meet requirements for certain able-bodied, childless adults to work or volunteer at least 20 hours a week. HMF was also caught paying for billboards in March alleging that certain House Republicans had voted to cut Medicaid despite the bill‚Äôs text not mentioning the entitlement program nor prescribing any specific policy directions. Several of the billboards were taken down after House Republicans‚Äô campaign arm sent a cease-and-desist letter to the vendor responsible for putting up the billboards.

title: A Qu√©b√©cois Socialist Response to Canada‚Äôs Federal Election
content: These elections took place in a climate of heightened Canadian nationalism. In Quebec, the Bloc adopted a nationalism compatible with federalism. Both forms of nationalism assume that national ...
resumen: In the recent federal election, despite predictions of a Conservative Party victory, the Liberal Party of Canada secured a fourth consecutive mandate. The campaign was dominated by concerns over the trade war and Donald Trump's threats, influencing voting intentions. The new government, led by Prime Minister Mark Carney, aims to defend the Canadian economy, reaffirm national sovereignty, and protect territorial unity. The Canadian bourgeoisie and its governments face pressure from a US administration. The election resulted in a minority government, highlighting a polarization around the two major neoliberal parties and marginalizing third parties. The Conservative Party championed an ultraliberal agenda, combining it with populist demagogy. The Liberal Party, under Carney, shifted right, adopting elements of the Conservative platform, while also promoting Canadian nationalism. The Bloc Qu√©b√©cois lost ground, and the independence movement faced an impasse. The left has been weakened by the NDP's actions, trade-union apathy, and the fragmentation of social movements. The Canadian and Quebec left can rebuild by breaking with nationalisms and uniting working classes, Indigenous peoples, and subaltern groups in a plurinational liberation project. This project must be feminist, anti-racist, socialist, and decolonial. It must link its action to an ecosocialist project. The results of the last elections show that everything must be rebuilt from a veritable field of ruins. Andr√© Frappier and Bernard Rioux are the authors of the article.

title: Market Implications Of Tariff Litigation And AI Spending
content: Regardless of the outcome of the tariff litigation, tariffs are likely to continue in some form. Falling recession odds and AI spending continue to send stocks higher.
resumen: The Court of International Trade (CIT) struck down the majority of the tariffs implemented by the Trump administration. The sectoral tariffs, for example, those on autos and steel, were not impacted by this ruling. The tariffs removed include the 10% universal tariff, the reciprocal tariffs, and the specific tariffs targeting China, Canada, and Mexico. According to Strategas, this would remove about $220 billion in tariffs, leaving just $40 billion of those implemented since the start of the year. Within less than 24 hours after the ruling, the US Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit granted a stay. Therefore, the tariffs will remain in place, and the US will not yet need to refund the tariff revenue collected to date. This litigation could be a lengthy process, but even if the tariffs are struck down at the end of the litigation, President Trump has the legal authority to reimpose tariffs via alternative methods. According to Strategas, Sections 338 and 122 of the Tariff Act of 1930 can be utilized quickly to reinstate many of the tariffs that are currently at risk. Section 338 allows for tariffs of up to 50% that take effect 30 days after announcement, with no time limit on their duration. Section 122 gives the president the authority to impose tariffs of up to 15% with immediate effect, but these tariffs can only remain in place for 150 days without congressional approval. Furthermore, Section 301 of the Trade Act of 1974 permits the imposition of tariffs following an investigation by the United States Trade Representative (USTR). It is doubtful that tariffs will go away unless President Trump decides that they are. On the margin, the possibility that the courts could remove the tariffs leaves the Trump administration with less leverage to negotiate trade deals with other countries. The tax bill passed by the US House of Representatives was debt-neutral if the revenue from the tariffs was included in the scoring. The economic calendar has the critical monthly jobs report on Friday. Expectations are for nonfarm payroll job growth to slow to 125,000 from 177,000 in April. The unemployment rate is expected to remain steady at 4.2%. President Trump imposed a 50% steel tariff late last Friday.

title: President Trump Can‚Äôt Quiet Reality, Neither Can The Federal Reserve
content: U.S. President Donald Trump (R) shakes hands with his nominee for the ... More chairman of the Federal Reserve Jerome Powell during a press event in the Rose Garden at the White House, November 2, ...
resumen:
President Trump warned Walmart to not raise prices in response to his imposition of tariffs. Economists and pundits reacted to Trump‚Äôs warning with a mix of horror and haughty disdain.

The foolishness of tariff imposition is magnified when the individual behind the implementation demands that prices not reflect the initial error.

The Federal Reserve is being treated as the adult in the room relative to Trump‚Äôs much-ridiculed child. In pretending that the central bank has a role in mitigating Trump‚Äôs errors, the central bank comes off as Trump‚Äôs equal in the foolish department.

The Fed thinks it can do to soften the higher price implications of tariffs.

If the Fed‚Äôs answer is that economic growth causes prices to rise (the Fed sees higher prices as ‚Äúinflation‚Äù), and that slower growth born of a higher Fed funds rate will weigh on prices, then economists should be reacting in horror and haughty disdain toward the Fed too.

Fed officials near monolithically embrace the discredited Phillips Curve, which says growth causes prices to rise.

Economic growth is an effect of investment, and it reveals itself in enhanced production techniques that increase production of market goods at ever lower prices.

The biggest informer of consumer prices is the number of tessellated hands and machines around the world at work in the production of market goods.

When global cooperation is compromised due to taxes like tariffs, or perhaps lockdowns, prices of market goods rise. Conversely, when meddling politicians leave production and people alone, cooperation soars in concert with falling prices.

The Fed is trying to arrogate to itself a role in tamping down the higher prices that it not unreasonably says will be an effect of his tariffs.

The Fed thinks it has a role here as it endlessly leaks to a compliant and rather worshipful media its fears about the price implications of the Trump tariffs.

The popular belief inside the Fed is that economic slowdowns push down prices.

Trump rates our scorn for wanting prices to not reflect his mindless imposition of tariffs, so does the Fed rate equal amounts of scorn for thinking its own market interventions can blunt those of the President.

title: How a man described as ‚Äòdumber than a sack of bricks‚Äô came to dominate global trade policy
content: The decline has been unprecedented by US standards and has created, or at least compounded, what‚Äôs often referred to as a Rust Belt from the Midwest to the Great Lakes, an area that spans from western ...
resumen: Peter Navarro, described as "dumber than a sack of bricks" by Elon Musk, is a key adviser to Donald Trump on trade policy. Navarro, 75, is the intellectual driving force behind global tariffs and Trump's attempt to rewire the global trading system. He gained influence with his 2011 book "Death by China," which portrays China as a major issue in world trade, arguing that Beijing engages in unfair practices. Navarro played a role in the first Trump administration, but his push for a more aggressive stance on China was initially limited. He participated in the Rudy Giuliani-led campaign to overturn the 2020 US election result and spent four months in prison for refusing to cooperate with the congressional inquiry into the January 6th attack on the US Capitol. He was appointed Trump‚Äôs senior counsellor for trade and manufacturing. Navarro was the brains behind Trump‚Äôs reciprocal tariff formula, which had no precedent in economic theory. The formula generated weird outcomes, such as a 47 per cent tariff on Madagascar's exports. Navarro is spearheading this protectionist drive. His academic standing was affected when it emerged he fabricated a person frequently quoted in his books. Navarro used to write get-rich-quick investment books. The US has lost close to 5 million manufacturing jobs since 2001, the year China joined the World Trade Organisation (WTO). Navarro penned a chapter in Project 2025 called ‚Äúthe case for fair trade‚Äù in which he makes the argument for action against China‚Äôs ‚Äúinstitutionalised aggression‚Äù. He states that the US‚Äôs big trade deficits have been so damaging.

title: Chinese shares fall in Hong Kong on new trade frictions with US
content: Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday, as heightened US-China trade tensions jolted market sentiment. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped as much as 2.9%, the most in more than ...
resumen: Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday, as heightened US-China trade tensions jolted market sentiment. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped as much as 2.9%, the most in more than six weeks, led by losses in technology and electric vehicle companies. The index underperformed all of its Asian peers, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 0.8%. The onshore market is closed for a holiday on Monday. Negotiations between the world‚Äôs two largest economies have deteriorated as they accused each other of walking away from the terms of their trade truce last month. President Donald Trump told reporters Friday that China ‚Äúviolated a big part of the agreement‚Äù the countries made in Geneva, while expressing confidence that a talk with Chinese President Xi Jinping could ease tensions. The Trump administration‚Äôs plans to broaden restrictions on China‚Äôs tech sector, with new regulations to capture subsidiaries of companies under US curbs, and place limits on Chinese students‚Äô visas ‚Äî also weighed on investor concerns. The Chinese government called on the US to immediately correct ‚Äúdiscriminatory‚Äù measures and uphold the consensus reached at their Geneva talks, it said in a statement Monday. Chinese stocks‚Äô weakness reflects ‚Äúgrowing pressure and concern, such as renewed chip curbs,‚Äù said Billy Leung, investment strategist at Global X ETFs in Sydney. ‚ÄúIn the near term, trade uncertainty, property weakness, and June liquidity stress could keep foreign flow light.‚Äù China‚Äôs residential property sales continued to fall in May, signalling the real estate slump is still weighing on an economy that‚Äôs under pressure from deflation and trade tensions. Despite a recent selloff, the offshore Chinese stocks gauge is still among the world‚Äôs top gainers so far this year, fueled by hopes for further domestic stimulus and artificial intelligence-driven optimism from local startup DeepSeek‚Äôs breakthrough. The HSCEI and the Hang Seng Index are both up over 12% year-to-date, beating a 6.7% gain in the MSCI Asia Pacific Index. A wave of listings by Chinese companies in Hong Kong is also stirring anticipation that a robust pipeline of debuts will drive the broader stock market higher.

title: US Stock Market Live: China vows response to US accusation on trade deal violation
content: Futures on Wall Street have begun trading on Sunday evening US time on a negative note amidst rising uncertainties on trade and geopolitical tensions. Both US and China traded barbs over the weekend ...
resumen:
US Stock Market Live: Dow futures are down up to 150 points, while the S&P 500 and nasdaq futures are down 20 and 90 points respectively.

US and China traded barbs over the weekend for violating a trade agreement that was reached in Geneva last month.

US has accused China of curbing the exports of rare earth magnets and other key minerals, while China has called out the US for their curbs on semiconductor exports.

US President Donald Trump also announced that he will be doubling the tariffs on steel and aluminium to 50% from 25%.

Rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine have also sent oil prices higher.

Wall Street had their best month since November 2023 after benchmark indices gained up to 6% in May.

The US Dollar index is back at 99.

Chinese shares traded in Hong Kong fell on Monday.

The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index dropped as much as 2.9%.

The MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 0.8%.

The dollar will tumble to levels last seen during the Covid-19 pandemic by the middle of next year, according to predictions by Morgan Stanley.

The US Dollar Index will fall about 9% to hit 91 by around this time next year.

Manufacturing activity across several Asian nations weakened in May as US tariffs and trade uncertainty eroded demand.

In Vietnam, new export orders contracted for a 7th straight month.

In Taiwan, output and new export sales all fell for a second month.

Indonesia saw the steepest drop in new orders since August 2021.

South Korean manufacturers recorded the deepest decline in output in nearly three years.

Vietnam, Indonesia, Taiwan, Japan and South Korea all recorded a contraction in overall activity, with the Purchasing Managers Index remaining below the 50-no change mark.

Gold rose ‚Äî after falling by 2% last week.

Bullion climbed as much as 0.8% in Asia.

Brent crude for August rose as much as 2.1% to $64.09 a barrel, after losing 2.2% last week, while West Texas Intermediate was around $62.

Ukraine struck air bases deep in Russia.

President Donald Trump said he would be increasing tariffs on steel and aluminum.

The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries and its allies agreed on Saturday to add 411,000 barrels a day of supply in July.

Ukraine staged a dramatic series of strikes across Russia.

More than 40 Russian aircraft, including the Tu-95 and Tu-22 M3 long-range bombers capable of deploying conventional and nuclear weapons as well as the A-50, are reported to have been damaged in the operation on Sunday, an official in Ukraine‚Äôs Security Service said.

China Hits Back At US‚Äì US actions against China are discriminatory. ‚Äì Repeatedly raised concerns regarding US abuse of export control measures in semiconductors. ‚Äì Urge the US to correct its erroneous actions and uphold the consensus reached in Geneva.

US President Donald Trump told reporters: ‚Äì China violated a big part of the agreement we made. ‚Äì I‚Äôll speak to President Xi and I‚Äôm sure we‚Äôll work that out. However,. ‚Äì China has not acknowledged Trump‚Äôs call demand with Xi yet. ‚Äì Last instance of Trump-Xi talking was before Trump‚Äôs inauguration in January.

The Dow futures are down over 100 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq futures are down 20 points and 90 points respectively.

title: MICHAEL LUCCI: US Multinationals Must Exit China
content: President Trump first called upon American businesses to find an alternative to China in August 2019. Few executives listened. Since ...
resumen: President Trump first called upon American businesses to find an alternative to China in August 2019. China‚Äôs global behavior has ranged from thuggish to explicitly war-like, including covid duplicity, underwriting Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine, fueling America‚Äôs fentanyl crisis, and preparing to invade Taiwan. Trump‚Äôs 2019 call has been completely validated. Investors should be asking U.S. multinational companies why they are still dependent upon China. American industry must execute its own Operation Warp Speed to rapidly extricate all sensitive supply chains from China. China is not a reliable jurisdiction for multinational companies. China began shattering global norms from the moment they entered the World Trade Organization in 2001, quickly dismissing intellectual property (IP) laws, ignoring trade rules, and leveraging state control to thwart competition and subsidize economic attacks upon America. China‚Äôs cheating accelerated while reciprocity was always delayed, allowing China to accumulate massive trade surpluses. The prospect of Chinese market access has been repeatedly dangled to keep U.S. businesses submissive. China signed a trade deal with President Trump on January 15th, 2020, then immediately reneged, falling well short of the new purchases they promised. The CCP continued to pillage $225 billion to $600 billion of U.S. intellectual property per year. China‚Äôs IP theft and industrial subsidies are part of a ‚Äúdeliberate and strategic‚Äù attempt by Beijing to skip research costs, deindustrialize global competitors, and ultimately undermine the manufacturing capacity (and thus defense production) of rivals. The CCP‚Äôs global malfeasance took center-stage during the covid pandemic. China lied about a lab leak that caused the catastrophic outbreak, then took extraordinary lengths to cover up its malfeasance. In violation of international law, China ‚Äì with full knowledge of its lethality ‚Äì delayed notifying the World Health Organization of the Wuhan contagion, all while travelers departed Wuhan for global destinations. The CCP directed its companies operating overseas to exfiltrate to China as much medical and personal protective equipment as they could obtain. It also nationalized its local production ‚Äì sweeping up American companies operating in China, including General Motors and 3M ‚Äì to produce medical supplies while denying export licenses to send medical products to America. In early 2022, China blessed Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine and has since funded and supplied Russia‚Äôs war machine. Kaja Kallas, the E.U.‚Äôs top diplomat, describes China as the ‚Äúmain sponsor‚Äù or Russia‚Äôs war, and recently noted that 80% of dual-use (civilian and military) goods enter Russia from China. The CCP has also dialed-up shipments of nitrocellulose, a key component in munitions, and Iskander missiles that have targeted Ukrainian cities. China is also sowing chaos across the Middle East, implicitly backing the murderous Hamas terrorists. Social media platforms under Beijing‚Äôs sway have directed a disinformation campaign against the Jewish state in hopes of weakening the West‚Äôs support for Israel and thus undermining American interests. China‚Äôs leaders have liaised with Hamas‚Äô leaders about the conflict. Large quantities of Chinese-made assault rifles, grenade launchers, sophisticated explosives and high-tech military equipment have reportedly been captured in Hamas warehouses. Chinese companies stand accused by the United States of providing Iranian-backed Houthis with satellite imagery and dual-use components to help them target American ships in the Red Sea. The Houthis have spared China-flagged ships in exchange for this assistance. Since Russia‚Äôs 2022 invasion of Ukraine, Chinese Communist Party leader Xi Jinping has been openly preparing to blockade and invade Taiwan. The PLA is hurtling toward conflict, from nearly constant invasion drills, to combat readiness measures, to crafting legal frameworks designed to justify an invasion. INDOPACOM Commander Samuel Paparo describes China‚Äôs drills as rehearsals for forced annexation. Two consecutive State Departments have found China to be engaged in genocide against minority groups, and the House Select Committee on the Chinese Communist Party found China‚Äôs government to be the ‚Äúprime mover‚Äù in America‚Äôs fentanyl crisis. President Trump‚Äôs tariff reprieve is unearned grace for most companies still dependent upon China. U.S. multinationals must finally see the writing on the wall and accelerate their departure from China. Michael Lucci is the Founder and CEO of State Armor, a 501(c)(3) non-profit advocating for state solutions to the global threats posed by the CCP.

title: A la espera de la cumbre en la Casa Blanca, Milei y Trump profundizan la relaci√≥n entre Argentina y EE.UU
content: Despu√©s de la visitas oficiales de Bessent y Kennedy, se aguarda la llegada a Buenos Aires del secretario de Energ√≠a, Chris Wright, que ya ...
resumen:
Despu√©s de la visitas oficiales de Bessent y Kennedy, se aguarda la llegada a Buenos Aires del secretario de Energ√≠a, Chris Wright, que ya exhibi√≥ su inter√©s por Vaca Muerta.

Javier Milei y Donald Trump durante su √∫ltimo encuentro en Maryland, (Estados Unidos).

La sinton√≠a personal e ideol√≥gica entre Javier Milei y Donald Trump caus√≥ un hecho in√©dito en la embajada argentina en Washington: fuera de protocolo, Chris Wright, secretario de Energ√≠a de Estados Unidos, particip√≥ de una mesa de trabajo para analizar la potencia econ√≥mica y estrat√©gica de Vaca Muerta.

Wright es un jugador clave en la administraci√≥n republicana y act√∫a coordinado con Marco Rubio -secretario de Estado- Scott Bessent, secretario del Tesoro.

Hace unos d√≠as, cuando Trump a√∫n dudada respecto a la continuidad de la licencia de Chevron en Venezuela, Wright se aline√≥ con Rubio para evitar que la pr√≥rroga de explotaci√≥n petrolera beneficiara a la dictadura de Nicol√°s Maduro.

El embajador argentino Alejandro Oxenford convoc√≥ al Council for a Secure Am√©rica (CSA) para debatir los posibles acuerdos energ√©ticos entre Argentina y Estados Unidos. Junto a Oxford participaron Juan Corteletti‚Äì jefe de Misi√≥n Adjunto- y Julia Hoppstock, consejera econ√≥mica y comercial.

Al otro lado de la mesa, se ubic√≥ el secretario Wright, que lleg√≥ a la embajada sin invitaci√≥n formal y se uni√≥ a representantes del √°rea energ√©tica de los Estados Unidos.

Alejandro Oxenford y Chris Wright durante la reuni√≥n que mantuvieron en la embajada de Argentina en Estados Unidos, (Washington).

Oxenford, Corteletti y Hoppstock desplegaron una sucesi√≥n de argumentos para sostener la viabilidad de la inversiones extranjeras en Vaca Muerta:
‚ÄìLa eficiencia y productividad de la zona de explotaci√≥n.
‚ÄìLa resiliencia del negocio frente a la volatilidad de los precios internacionales del petr√≥leo.
‚ÄìLa ventaja comparativa de Argentina en el desarrollo del sector no convencional.
‚ÄìEl rol estrat√©gico que desempe√±an las empresas y tecnolog√≠as estadounidenses en la transformaci√≥n de Vaca Muerta.

Cuando termin√≥ el c√≥nclave, Oxenford invit√≥ a Wright a la Argentina, y el secretario de Energ√≠a acept√≥ la invitaci√≥n formal.

Ahora, todo depender√° de la agenda de Wright para 2025.

‚ÄúEl sector energ√©tico es uno de los ejes prioritarios en la relaci√≥n bilateral entre Argentina y Estados Unidos, tanto desde una perspectiva geopol√≠tica como en t√©rminos de atracci√≥n de inversiones, generaci√≥n de empleo y desarrollo econ√≥mico sostenible en nuestro pa√≠s‚Äù, coment√≥ Oxenford tras su encuentro de trabajo con el secretario Wright.

La probable visita de Wright a la Argentina exhibe los lazos profundos entre el gobierno de Milei y la administraci√≥n Trump.

Balcarce 50 necesita inversiones directas que permitan fortalecer las reservas del Banco Central, y la reuni√≥n entre Wright y Oxenford apunt√≥ a ese objetivo geoecon√≥mico.

Ya hubo una avance con el viaje rel√°mpago de Scott Bessent -secretario del Tesoro- a Buenos Aires, y se espera que el canciller Gerardo Werthein regrese a Washington tras la gira de Milei por Europa y Medio Oriente.

Argentina negocia con Estados Unidos un acuerdo que permita atenuar el impacto de los aranceles rec√≠procos impuestos por Trump a las exportaciones nacionales, y no se descarta en DC que una misi√≥n t√©cnica de la Canciller√≠a aterrice en el aeropuerto Reagan antes que concluya junio.

La Casa Blanca exigi√≥ al gobierno libertario que elimine ciertas barreras arancelarias y profundas distorsiones legales en el uso de patentes de propiedad intelectual para llegar a un acuerdo en las pr√≥ximas semanas.

Javier Milei, Luis Caputo, y Gerardo Werthein durante la cumbre del Mercosur, (Montevideo, Uruguay).

El Palacio San Mart√≠n y el Ministerio de Econom√≠a trabajan en t√°ndem para satisfacer las exigencias de la Secretaria de Comercio y la Oficina del Representante Comercial de los Estados Unidos (USTR), pero es una tarea compleja que depende del resultado electoral de octubre.

Milei, Caputo y Werthein necesitan de una mayor√≠a s√≥lida en Diputados y el Senado para resolver los planteos legales que se hacen en el √∫ltimo informe de la USTR, y eso ocurrir√≠a si el gobierno obtiene un triunfo electoral hacia fin de a√±o.

Mientras tanto, la Casa Blanca a√∫n define cuando Milei y Trump se encontrar√°n en el Sal√≥n Oval. El 4 de julio, de hecho, empiezan las vacaciones de verano en Washington.

title: 'This is a roller coaster ride': How Trump's tariffs turned the 'TACO' trade into Wall Street's biggest debate
content: Ongoing US-China trade tensions and volatile policy shifts have left investors caught between betting on tariff deescalations and bracing for increased uncertainty.
resumen:
The "TACO" trade, an acronym for "Trump Always Chickens Out," captures a growing belief among investors that the president talks tough on tariffs but rarely follows through. This has fueled a market tailwind in recent months.

This week, Trump lashed out at China, accusing the country of having "violated" its trade deal with the US. Bloomberg reported that the Trump administration plans to expand tech restrictions on China.

Stocks have not only erased their "Liberation Day" losses, but the S&P 500 (^GSPC) secured its best May since 1990 and had the best month since Nov. 2023.

Julie Beale, chief market strategist at Kayne Anderson Rudnick, referenced a reporter's question to Trump earlier in the week about the trade. In response, Trump slammed the term. Beale worries that this may cause Trump to be more resilient on tariffs.

Rapid policy shifts mean that the downside risk could become significantly more pronounced if Trump decides to hold firm on tariffs.

S&P Global chief economist Paul Gruenwald said, "This is a roller coaster ride. Not good for long-term planning and not good for corporate investment."

A Manhattan-based trade court struck down a wide swath of Trump's tariffs, citing legal issues. A federal appeals court paused that decision on Thursday.

Callie Cox, chief market strategist at Ritholtz Wealth Management, urged investors to look beyond the tariff drama and focus on economic data, especially the jobs report coming up next week, and what the Fed is doing in response to all of this data. Cox noted the Federal Reserve has limited ability to intervene if the economy weakens.

title: Fed‚Äôs Waller Hints at Potential Rate Cuts Despite Tariff-Driven Inflation Risks
content: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said interest rate cuts remain on the table for 2025, even as President Donald Trumps new tariffs are expected to temporarily lift inflation. Speaking in ...
resumen: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said interest rate cuts remain on the table for 2025, even as President Donald Trump‚Äôs new tariffs are expected to temporarily lift inflation. Speaking in Seoul, Waller emphasized that he would ‚Äúlook through‚Äù the near-term inflationary impact of tariffs when setting monetary policy. If inflation keeps trending toward the Fed‚Äôs 2% target and the job market remains strong, Waller supports what he called ‚Äúgood news‚Äù rate cuts later this year. He noted that April‚Äôs inflation data and a resilient labor market provide space to monitor how the economy evolves amid trade uncertainty. Waller‚Äôs comments diverge from more cautious Fed voices, as he acknowledged short-term risks from higher import duties. He sees potential inflation spikes in the second half of 2025 but characterized them as likely one-time effects. He added that if tariffs stay around 10%, the full price impact may not be passed on to consumers. The Fed official highlighted that current inflation expectations from markets and professional forecasters remain stable. Waller also addressed rising bond yields, attributing them partly to growing concerns about U.S. debt and foreign investor sentiment amid protectionist trade policies. He warned that a "risk-off" mood among foreign buyers of U.S. assets could be emerging due to anti-investment signals from Washington. Overall, Waller‚Äôs remarks suggest that the Fed is prepared to adjust rates if economic conditions allow, despite political and inflationary headwinds tied to Trump‚Äôs evolving trade agenda.

title: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon says he wouldn't count on China folding under Trump's tariffs: 'They're not scared, folks.'
content: Jamie Dimon appeared at the 2025 Reagan National Economic Forum on Friday, saying he's concerned if the US can "get our own act together." ...
resumen: JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon spoke at the 2025 Reagan National Economic Forum on Friday. Dimon said he hoped the US could "get our own act together" amid the US-China trade war. Trump said China "violated" its trade agreement with the US this week. JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon said the United States needs to get its act together on trade ‚Äî quickly. Dimon discussed the ongoing tension between the United States and China on Friday at the 2025 Reagan National Economic Forum, where he led a fireside chat. When asked what his biggest worry was right now, Dimon pointed to the shifting global geopolitical and economic landscape, including trade. "We have problems and we've got to deal with them," Dimon said before referring to "the enemy within." Addressing the "enemy within," he said, includes fixing how the United States approaches permitting, regulation, taxation, immigration, education, and the healthcare system. It also means maintaining important military alliances, he said. "China is a potential adversary. They're doing a lot of things well. They have a lot of problems," Dimon said. "What I'm really worried about is us. Can we get our own act together? Our own values, our own capabilities, our own management." Dimon said that if the United States is not the "preeminent military and preeminent economy in 40 years, we will not be the reserve currency. That's a fact." Although Dimon believes the United States is usually resilient, he said things are different this time around. "We have to get our act together, and we have to do it very quickly," he said. During the conversation, Dimon spoke about trade deals and encouraged US leaders to engage with China. "I just got back from China last week," Dimon said. "They're not scared, folks. This notion that they're going to come bow to America, I wouldn't count on that." Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent disagreed with Dimon during a Sunday appearance on CBS's "Face the Nation." "Jamie is a great banker. I know him well, but I would vociferously disagree with that assessment," Bessent said. "That the laws of economics and gravity apply to the Chinese economy and the Chinese system, just like everyone else." Trump's decision to impose tariffs on numerous countries, including steep tariffs on China, rattled global markets earlier this year. Markets recovered after many countries, including China, began negotiating. But the possibility that tariffs could increase again at any time has investors and economists on edge. On Friday, for instance, in a Truth Social post, Trump accused China of violating the two countries' trade agreement. That same day, Trump said he planned to increase tariffs on steel imports from 25% to 50%. "We're going to bring it from 25% to 50%, the tariffs on steel into the United States of America, which will even further secure the steel industry in the United States. Nobody's going to get around that," Trump said during a rally near Pittsburgh.

title: President‚Äôs Top Aides Insist Tariffs Are Here to Stay
content: President Trump‚Äôs top economic advisers stressed on Sunday that they would not be deterred by a recent court decision declaring many of the administration‚Äôs tariffs to be illegal, pointing to other ...
resumen:
*   On Saturday night, President Trump shared a conspiracy theory on social media, stating that former President Joseph R. Biden had been "executed in 2020" and replaced by a robotic clone.
*   Mr. Trump reposted a fringe rant from another user on Truth Social.
*   President Trump withdrew his nomination of Jared Isaacman as NASA administrator on Saturday, citing a review of his ‚Äúprior associations,‚Äù a veiled reference to donations Mr. Isaacman had made to Democrats.
*   Mr. Isaacman had made donations to Democrats, including to former Senator Bob Casey, the Pennsylvania Democrat who lost his seat in 2024, and to the California Democratic Party. He also donated more than once to Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona.
*   Senator Rand Paul, Republican from Kentucky, said in an interview on CBS‚Äôs ‚ÄúFace the Nation‚Äù that he thought there was a total of four Republican senators, including himself, who would block the president‚Äôs signature domestic policy bill as currently written.
*   Martin Makary, the commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, defended the federal government‚Äôs decision to stop formally recommending the Covid vaccine for healthy children and healthy pregnant women.
*   President Trump is golfing at his Virginia property today with Bryson DeChambeau, winner of the 2024 U.S. Open.
*   President Trump‚Äôs top economic advisers stressed on Sunday that they would not be deterred by a recent court decision declaring many of the administration‚Äôs tariffs to be illegal.
*   Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, said that tariffs are not going away.
*   Kevin Hassett, the director of the White House National Economic Council, said the expectation is that President Trump and China‚Äôs leader, Xi Jinping, could next speak about trade as soon as this week.
*   Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent reiterated that economic talks with China remain stalled, and claimed that the deadlock was due to China holding back exports of rare earth minerals.
*   Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent expressed optimism that Republicans would pass their far-reaching domestic policy bill this summer and said that President Trump‚Äôs campaign promises would be priorities in the legislation.
*   Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent defended the Trump administration‚Äôs increased steel tariffs.
*   Howard Lutnick, the commerce secretary, said he does not anticipate an ‚Äúextension‚Äù for President Trump‚Äôs 90-day pause on his so-called reciprocal tariffs, which is set to expire in July.
*   Speaker Mike Johnson, Republican of Louisiana, said he texted Elon Musk to respond to the billionaire‚Äôs recent criticism of the One Big, Beautiful Bill Act that passed in the House last month.
*   According to a confidential U.N. report, Iran now has the capability to produce bomb-grade fuel for roughly 10 weapons.
*   The United States presented its first formal proposal to Tehran for elements of a nuclear deal on Saturday.
*   The document calls for Iran to cease all enrichment of uranium and proposes the creation of a regional consortium to produce nuclear power that would involve Iran; Saudi Arabia and other Arab states; and the United States.
*   The revelation of Iran‚Äôs production surge of uranium enriched to 60 percent, just below bomb-grade, was a vivid illustration of its effort to gain leverage in the negotiation. The increase gives Tehran the capability to produce the fuel for roughly 10 weapons, up from around five or six when President Trump was inaugurated in January.
*   The American Civil Liberties Union asked a federal appeals court early Saturday morning to stop President Trump from using a rarely invoked 18th-century law to deport scores of Venezuelans accused of being gang members to a prison in El Salvador.
*   The A.C.L.U. is challenging the use of the Alien Enemies Act.
*   The Justice Department is scheduled to file its brief in the case on June 17 and oral arguments are set to be held in New Orleans on June 30.
